TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement yesterday that a jobs levy is an option. I ask: does this mean that, despite previous denials, the government is still contemplating a wealth tax? Is this not further evidence of the government caving in to the ACTU?
—Do you know what a wealth tax is?
—The minister might tell us what the government has in mind in relation to a wealth tax. Has the Prime Minister again conveniently forgotten his pre-election promise of no new taxes?

—There is no connection whatsoever between a wealth tax and some sort of levy on high income earners, which has been the subject of some speculation and which the Prime Minister said yesterday might be regarded as an option. Beyond that, I have no further comment because clearly it is not a matter to which the government has at this stage devoted any policy attention at all.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Obviously, my supplementary question relates to the very limited explanation the minister just gave when he said that there is no relationship between a tax on high earners and a wealth tax. I, therefore, ask the minister to expand on what the Prime Minister means when he refers to a jobs levy. In particular, what sort of income cut-off level does the government have in mind? What sort of rate would it be? Let us into the secret.
—This is not the occasion for a kind of bubs grade lecture on the difference between wealth and income. Beyond that, I have no further comment.

—I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. In view of the government's encouragement to industry and commerce to use new technology to increase productivity, can the minister advise the Senate whether the government itself is taking any steps to use such technology to modernise and improve the efficiency of its purchasing processes? If the government is taking such steps, what benefits will initiatives in this area bring to government purchasers and industry suppliers?

—Senator Colston has raised an important question. There has been interest for some time in the recognition of the importance of EDI, electronic data interchange, in the development of more efficient business processes in the public sector and private industry. There has been active involvement in this area. The department, in particular, has been investigating for some time the use of new technology to support more efficient business processes. These investigations have shown that there is the potential for significant savings—in response particularly to one of Senator Colston's points—for the government through the introduction of electronic purchasing practices.

PARA.TAB: In fact, just last month a contract was signed between the department and the BHP Information Technology to develop and build a pilot electronic data interchange gateway, whereby BHP will supply hardware, software and services to run the project. Initial implementation and testing has started and we are hoping that services will be extended progressively through 1994.

The project will establish the viability and benefits of electronic trading to the government and to its suppliers. I am very confident, and it seems self-evident I would have thought, that electronic trading can bring significant benefits to government purchasing activities. There also seems to me to be significant potential in benefits to industry, including time savings on both sides, reduced paperwork, simplified procedures, reductions in errors and lower prices for goods and services.

The government is running educational awareness programs to help managers within the Public Service gain a better understanding of the benefits of electronic trading. Given that the Commonwealth spends about $10 billion a year on goods and services, it seems a significant contribution to economic efficiency in the country if there is a coordinated approach. This project has the potential to lead in that process and to create significant benefits for industry and for efficient government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the minister agree that Mr Keating's pulling of the rug from under his Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, by endorsing the Kelty policy to form small enterprise unions to negotiate workplace deals, clearly signals the government's formal capitulation to the strong ACTU campaign to ensure that unions hold their monopoly power over enterprise bargaining?

—No, that is not the case at all, as Senator Chapman would wholly expect me to say, and I say so for very good reason. The situation is that the government remains determined to further reform the industrial relations system by increasing its flexibility and by accelerating and widening the spread of enterprise bargaining. The government will do that cooperatively and constructively. We will not do it by allowing for reduced wages and conditions. We will not do it by emasculating trade unions. Our approach to industrial relations reform will continue in that respect to differentiate us from the opposition's wholly confrontational agenda. We believe that a permanent and reliable safety net, in effect, is essential to industrial relations reform and we will therefore continue to be committed to legislating for minimum standards to apply to all workers and to maintaining and updating the award system to protect those who are unable to negotiate workplace agreements.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth has argued before the Industrial Relations Commission that it ought to replace the current wage fixing principles with a statement of guidance based on the accord mark 7. We are committed to establishing clear and balanced industrial rights and responsibilities and to providing for effective enforcement within the context of the industrial relations system, rather than through the common law system which is costly, slow and inaccessible to ordinary workers. They are the elements of the government's current approach to industrial relations. That is an approach which I am sure will be capable of being thoroughly and effectively implemented in a constructive and cooperative, rather than confrontational, way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister's answer confirms the government's intention now to maintain the monopoly position of trade unions. I ask how the minister reconciles that answer with the fact that on 22 July at the National Press Club, the Prime Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: We would like to see a change away from a centralised structure where those who are not members of unions have the benefit of those changes.
Why does the minister not concede that his Prime Minister has made yet another gold medal backflip and that compulsory unionism remains the name of the game?

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not remain the name of the game. The name of the game is exactly as I described it. Might I just add this further comment on the subject of workplace bargaining: we, of course, recognise that there are lots of employees who, for one reason or another, cannot participate in workplace bargaining because they do not have a union to represent them. Our overriding concern is with the objective of spreading enterprise agreements. We have made that clear, as the Prime Minister did back in July, and we continue to do so. We formed a working party with the ACTU to discuss that issue. We will be considering a solution to the problem as a result of that exercise, and that response will be considered by cabinet in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I draw the minister's attention to the series of murders of young children in various parts of Australia. What is the federal government doing to address the problem of violence against children?

—The incidence of child abuse does appear to be rising in this country. The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare reported that in 1991-92 more than 50,000 reports of abuse were brought to attention in Australia. That represents a 7.7 per cent increase in cases over the previous year and a 20 per cent increase in cases since 1988-89. Whether that is a real increase or whether it is just a reflection of more people being prepared to report cases of child abuse is not known. But either way, it is somewhat irrelevant because what we do know is that child abuse, whatever the size or amount of it, is totally unacceptable.

PARA.TAB: Just as we have moved as a government—and the opposition is with us on this one—to make clear the refusal to tolerate violence against women, I think we now have to move to make sure that the issue of child abuse is equally unacceptable to all levels of society. The Commonwealth has recognised the seriousness of this issue. It addressed it by establishing a national child prevention council in 1991. That council has now produced the first ever prevention strategy for child abuse in this nation, and I was able to release that yesterday. That council has not only produced a strategy but it has established a clearing house on research into child abuse. That is very important because we do not know the amount or the size of this problem, nor do we know the multi-factor causes of it.

Until now the efforts to deal with child abuse have mostly involved trying to treat cases once they are diagnosed. This government's national strategy is moving to early intervention and even prevention of child abuse. We recognise that the cost of child abuse is just appalling, not only in straight dollar costs but also in terms of the consequences. We want to break the cycle of child abuse of whatever sort being passed on from one generation to another.

As I said, we do not know the causes of child abuse. We do know that many of the parents who are guilty of child abuse report having been abused themselves as children. That is not true of all adults who were abused as children, but there is certainly a high figure in respect of parents of abused children. So I think it is vitally important that government makes clear its commitment to breaking that cycle, to trying to interrupt the passing on of very unhappy, destructive childhood experiences and child abuse practices that may, when the children grow into adults, affect their behaviour. The cost is far too high—not only in terms of dollars but also in terms of the damage done to members and representatives of our community.

With the launch of this strategy, I have written to all my state and territory colleagues seeking their support for the implementation of this preventive strategy and for cost sharing funding arrangements so that we can proceed to see whether we cannot make a difference in this quite horrible, shocking condition that is confronting our society. I think we must also not be distracted by the kinds of cases that draw the headlines in our newspapers. Child abuse is much wider and much deeper, and sometimes one could say that more ordinary abuse is occurring. We must concentrate on making sure that all of those families that suffer abuse, not just the headline cases, are equally the concern of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Given the public concern and debate over the portrayal of violence on television, can the minister advise the Senate of progress over the registration of new codes of conduct for commercial television stations?
—I think we are all indebted to the initiative of the Prime Minister—
—What about a code of conduct for you? You'd never agree to it!

—He got a lot of kicks for it at the time, so I think that he is due for a little credit for it now. It is a timely question because under the Broadcasting Services Act broadcasters are required to develop codes relating to programming matters and complaints procedures. The Australian Broadcasting Authority on 19 August endorsed a code of practice which will form the basis for commercial television program regulation. The code of practice was developed by the Federation of Commercial Television Stations, FACTS, after extensive consultation with the television industry, the public and the Australian Broadcasting Authority and took effect yesterday.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the consultation, safeguards have been strengthened in relation to program classification, advertising time, program promotions and the portrayal of women and indigenous peoples in the media. Some senators may have seen these new classifications on television last night and I think they will agree that more useful information is now being provided to the viewing public than before.

One of the most important aspects of the code of practice is the new classification information about programs. Last night the new classification information provided this information before the Sunday night movie. A summary of this information was also screened after each ad break during the movie. Significantly, the code introduces the new M and MA classifications to television. This means there is now a uniform treatment of classification across cinema, film, video and television—something that people have been wanting for a long time.

While M—soft mature material—films can be shown after 8.30 p.m., MA, mature adult films and programs in which there is a high level of violence and sexual depictions, may only be broadcast between 9 p.m. and 5 a.m. M and MA classification programs must carry in addition to the classification symbol brief on-screen consumer advice detailing the main elements which have contributed to the classification. These are—honourable senators opposite should listen carefully because I know some of them are going to find it hard to work this out—S for sex, L for language, V for violence, D for drug use, H for horror and A for adult themes.

This consumer advice is designed to assist viewers in making informed choices about their own viewing and, importantly, that of their children. The ultimate decision again, as it always has been, is in the hands of parents but at least they will have better advice on which to base those decisions.

In relation to the calculation of advertising time, the prime time viewing ban has been extended to cover the period 6 p.m. to midnight. This will give broadcasters greater flexibility to take into account different program styles when scheduling non-program matter. The code also includes a new complaints procedure. If people wish to complain about programs, they must now first make their complaint to the particular broadcaster. If a response is not received within 60 days or is unsatisfactory, the ABA can be asked to investigate.

This new code, which will operate in conjunction with the ABA's program standards regulating Australian content and children's television, represents a significant step forward, as envisaged by the Prime Minister, in alerting parents to the content of evening television in a simple and effective way, helping parents select what is or is not appropriate for viewing by a young audience.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications: how does he expect the Australian shipping industry to contribute to boosting Australia's competitive position when his government's budget mark 2 has increased fuel taxes by $358,387 annually for an average vessel, which far outweighs the $270,000 per vessel reduction in annual operating costs from shipping reforms? I further ask him: why is his government's budget geared to deliberately putting more Australians out of work?

—I will ignore the nonsense in the last part of the question. In answer to the first part of the question, I can advise Senator Parer that the government has the matter of the fuel oil excise under consideration at the moment.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister explain to the Senate what he means by `having this matter under consideration'?
—Exactly what I said.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is the minister aware of comments made by Mr Bruce Ruxton at the RSL's recent national congress, urging the Australian Defence Force to station troops in Papua New Guinea? Can the minister advise the Senate of his views on this proposal?

—I am aware of the remarks made by Mr Ruxton at the RSL national congress. I also note that the congress is reported as having rejected Mr Ruxton's approach. I also reject this approach for a number of reasons. Papua New Guinea is an independent and sovereign nation and as such it is inappropriate for the Australian government to consider stationing ADF combat troops in Bougainville or elsewhere in Papua New Guinea.

PARA.TAB: The Australian government has provided practical help to assist PNG address our shared security concerns through ADF loan and exchange personnel, training and project assistance under the defence cooperation program, and combined exercises. The defence cooperation for 1993-94 is estimated at $28 million and there will be more than 38 loan and exchange personnel serving the Papua New Guinea defence force.

In accordance with the longstanding arrangements between the Australian and Papua New Guinea governments on the use of Australian loan personnel in any politically sensitive situation, I have on occasion approved specific requests from the PNG government for ADF personnel serving with the PNG security force to visit Bougainville in order to assist with the restoration of communications and to assess requirements for infrastructure repair. The government has stated previously that the Bougainville conflict is an internal matter for the PNG government to resolve. At the same time, it is my view that the situation is not susceptible to a purely military solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the minister confirm that some $8,250 worth of antique light fittings has been recently purchased for the Prime Minister's Lodge from antique dealer Mr Paul Kenny? Was Mr Kenny the same antique dealer involved in supplying the reproduction Thai teak dining table? Is it also a fact that Mr Kenny's direct access to the Prime Minister is a result of his having been the Prime Minister's business partner? Has anything changed?
—Getting down to the big issues.

—It is a real big issue—about Senator Campbell's speed, though, in terms of his track record. I am advised that the lights in the Lodge dining room were recently replaced because they were inadequate. The Official Establishments Trust has been aware for some time of the need to replace the previous light fittings which were an interim installation pending the availability of more suitable lights. I do not know from whom the lights were purchased nor would I have thought that, on the face of it, the order of magnitude of the dollar sum involved was such as to raise even a prima facie question about the appropriateness of that purchase.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. It may be a trifling matter for Senator Gareth Evans and other people who live in luxury at the taxpayers' expense, but it matters to the people of Australia that we can afford to spend $8,000 on some lights when most people out there cannot afford to spend $100 on a light. Will Senator Gareth Evans get some answers to my questions? Furthermore, could he please answer the question as to when the Prime Minister will stop worrying about his own personal comfort at home at the Lodge and start worrying about the comfort of a million people out there who are unemployed at the moment?

—The fact that the Lodge is, in terms of its furnishing and general habitation standards, the subject of close scrutiny and control by the Official Establishments Trust is indication in itself that we are not talking about something which is simply a private dwelling but a national architectural asset. It should be viewed as such; it always has been viewed as such by successive Tory Prime Ministers who have inhabited the Lodge with varying degrees of style over the years. I will ask the Prime Minister's office if there is any further information that should be supplied but again, I repeat, there is no ground whatsoever for the kind of imputations that underlie Senator Campbell's question.

—I address my question to the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware of an article that appeared in the Age on Friday, 3 September, referring to a letter from the President of the Royal Australian College of Opthamologists to the minister concerning rorts by optometrists? What evidence is there of such rorts being in existence? What can be done to ensure that the payment of Medicare funds for eye disorders is only made for those services which come within the Medicare benefits scheme?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. I did see the article from Dr Ian Favilla in which the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists fleshed out the complaints it has against the optometrists in Australia. The college had in fact made some of these allegations to me verbally a couple of months ago and, as of last Wednesday, it has put those concerns in writing.

PARA.TAB: It is true that it is claiming that up to $22 million a year in savings could be made if there were a clampdown on the way optometrists conduct their business. It would appear that this is based on saying that the numbers of optometrists are growing rapidly and hence their services are growing rapidly and that optometrists are in fact seeing people quite often for the treatment of ocular systematic medical conditions for which, according to the ophthalmologists, the optometrists have no training or legislative right to treat. As a result of these suggestions, I am asked to investigate the matter.

Obviously, when one is confronted with allegations of $22 million a year being improperly taken from the public purse, one has to look at it, and I certainly shall be. I have in fact asked that we have a special look at this question of eye disorders and the way they are treated. That having been said, I think one really has to see the correspondence I have received from the ophthalmologists as part of what has been a very long-term campaign by them against optometry which they see as having invaded their patch to some extent. It is interesting to note that the optometrists do not seem to retaliate. Perhaps after the last couple of weeks they will feel more empowered to do so, but at this stage of the game because I have these on the table I will be having a look at it.

I think one thing the controversy over the last couple of weeks about optometry has done, in generating more interest, is convince me that perhaps we need a close look at the way we are paying out money for eye disorders of all kinds. I think we will be having a very good look at optometrists and ophthalmologists over the course of the next few months to make sure the integrity of the government dollar is being protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to the Commonwealth Development Bank which currently provides finance to some 48,000 farmers and fishermen. The Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill seeks to change the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank and also to sell off another 20 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which is its parent. Can the government guarantee that the Commonwealth Development Bank will not cease to act as a lender of last resort to our farmers and fishermen? Will changing the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank lessen or remove its existing community obligations in any way?

—I thank Senator O'Chee for his question. PARA.TAB: That is a somewhat limited response to a slightly broader question that Senator O'Chee asked, although I think it goes to the core of it. I am not confident I have covered all of the matters, so I will check with the Treasurer and if there is any further material, I will provide it to Senator O'Chee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I thank the minister and ask a supplementary question. If I were a farmer who already had a first and second mortgage existing over the property and sought to get top up financing or supplementary financing in the existing fashion, which I could now, would my opportunity to get that financing be lessened in any way as a result of these changes?

—On the basis of the information I have, to the extent there would be any change at all, I think it would be marginally enhanced. But I will include a response to that in the indication which I have already given of further information which I will provide.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and relates to the national plan to combat marine oil pollution. I refer to the minister's statement last year responding to the report from the investigation into the Kirki incident, when that tanker lost its bow off the Western Australian coast. In that statement reference was made to a review of Australia's national strategy for responding to the significant pollution threat from a shipping accident. Can the minister advise on the findings of the review and their implementation?

—The Natplan review was commenced after the Kirki incident. The review was headed by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and involved both federal and state governments and representatives from the oil, petroleum exploration and shipping industries. A comprehensive report was presented from that review to the last meeting of ATAC, the Transport Ministers Council, which adopted the review's recommendations. They included the acquisition of an additional $5.6 million worth of pollution combat equipment to provide an improved initial response capability in high risk areas. Natplan now incorporates management of some $30 million worth of oil spill response equipment; an improved national training program for response personnel to ensure prompt and effective action to an oil spill incident; enhanced arrangements for the rapid response of personnel and equipment; clearer command and control procedures for managing the response to a marine incident; and closer integration of existing government and industry response capabilities. These recommendations are now being implemented and a national plan advisory committee, comprising government and industry representatives, is overseeing this process.

PARA.TAB: The ministerial council also agreed to AMSA undertaking a public awareness campaign to ensure better community understanding about Australia's capacity to respond to oil spills at sea. To this end, AMSA has published the review report and will be circulating copies to all federal members of parliament and appropriate community groups. It will be seeking to publicise the report which will be available through the Australian Government Publishing Service. It is planned to officially launch the publicity campaign with a media conference on Thursday of this week to coincide with a Natplan training course demonstration of oil spill equipment in Sydney sponsored by AMSA.

I commend all honourable senators and honourable members, particularly those with coastal electorates, to use the review report as a resource to improve local knowledge of Australia's national marine oil spill contingency plan and to encourage public assistance with reporting of oil spills and education of community groups to assist in clean-up operations. The best defence without question to oil pollution is to ensure that the oil stays inside the ship. Hence, the government is continuing its campaign against unsound and unsafe ships in the government response to the Ships of Shame report which will be tabled today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The minister will be aware of the disastrous national strike of coalminers which, apart from putting us back into the category of unreliable suppliers, cost Australia an estimated $100 million in lost production, and thus export earnings. Is it not a fact that the strike would have been prolonged but for section 45D of the Trade Practices Act?

—The decision by the united mineworkers to return to work on Sunday is to be welcomed, but I think we have to get some perspective about it. The first thing is that, as I am advised, the concern of the mineworkers in this matter was not that they were in pursuit of enhanced conditions for themselves; it was in response to a concern they had that the coal companies were setting prices which were lower than could have been achieved and seeking to recoup the shortfall by calling on mineworkers to accept wage cuts or to deny coalminers a share in the benefits of the improved productivity.

PARA.TAB: I am not commenting on the merits of that claim. It is not for me to do so here. Even if I were the Minister for Industrial Relations, I would not do so, and I certainly will not do it in here when I am merely representing him, but I think it is important to remember that, in terms of getting the claim into perspective. There have been people seeking to interpret both the development of the dispute and its resolution to suit their particular political point of view. Senator Parer is not unique in that. He joins a rather long line of people who have sought to do it.

The Coal Industry Tribunal issued return to work orders on 2 and 3 September 1993 and the united mineworkers recommended a return to work at midnight on the fifth. Those who were not at the meeting of the mineworkers—and neither Senator Parer nor I was—cannot know what were the various factors at play. We cannot hypothesise what might have happened in the changed industrial relations law setting that would follow from Australia taking what I think is the internationally responsible decision to deal with sections 45D and 45E, such that our laws dealing with industrial relations are no longer the subject of that criticism from the ILO which it has directed at those particular sections. There will be a new industrial relations framework when those changes are made. We can only hypothesise what might have been the situation with regard to this particular dispute or any other had they been conducted under those proposed new laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister advise the Senate whether he agrees with the reason given by the united mineworkers to go on strike simply because the mineworkers themselves considered that BHP had sold coal to Turkey, having obtained a contract in opposition to the Americans at a price below which the miners themselves considered equitable? Is it not a fact that one of the major reasons for this silly dispute was the attempt by the mineworkers to have some sort of a national marketing authority? Is it not also a fact that the dispute was stopped only because of the effect of section 45D? Is it not time the minister and everyone else on the Labor side stopped trying to fool everyone?
—The supplementary question does not add anything. It is merely a slightly more over the top reiteration of the first question. The answer which I gave to the first question stands.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services. I draw the minister's attention to a press release put out by the South Australian Council of Social Services on 17 August which claims that funding for emergency financial assistance through non-government community agencies was cut in the budget by more than 50 per cent. Is funding under the emergency relief program for such emergency financial assistance to be reduced? Given that agencies such as the Brisbane City Mission are reporting that the number of people approaching them asking for help has increased by 58 per cent in the last year, is the government simply expecting these agencies to do much more with less?

—No, the report is inaccurate, the funding for emergency relief was not cut by 50 per cent; and no, the emergency financial assistance is not to be reduced. In fact, the base funding for emergency relief in the budget is over $17.6 million, compared with the $2.5 million for this item when this government took office and the $15.35 million in 1992-93, so there is a modest increase on the amount of money allocated last year.

PARA.TAB: The most important thing the government is concerned about is not that we should be assisting people as though life were a series of crises, but hoping that they will be directed to the ongoing assistance the government provides for people who are facing, in particular, financial difficulties. Those kinds of services include the family allowance supplement, particularly paid to low income families; the mortgage and rent assistance program, which has been allocated $30.9 million this financial year for short-term mortgage and rent relief; rent assistance provided by the Department of Social Security; and child-care fee relief, which is up to $92.50 per child per week, along with the considerable child-care services this government provides.

In addition to that, the government will provide more than $103 million this year, including growth funds of $3.5 million, for the supported accommodation assistance program. Senator Woodley would know that one particular item of the SAAP deals with crisis accommodation, meals and support for homeless people. So the government is much more concerned that the ongoing and continuing programs for assistance for people in crisis be the way that we assist people rather than through an emergency program.

—I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Can the minister report on changes in the diagnosis pattern of HIV? Will the minister comment particularly on the risk factor for women contracting this disease?
—Is this a confidence building exercise?

—I am very pleased to acknowledge my colleague Senator Patterson's presence at the launch this morning of the very important report Becoming Aware produced by family planning. The report recognises very much the changing pattern in the presence of AIDS and the AIDS virus in Australia. We have actually been very fortunate in this country, perhaps because we were also very quickly responsible. The government's program to tackle AIDS has seen a very effective result.

PARA.TAB: The rate of increase in the number of cases of AIDS is now falling but, curiously enough, while it is falling overall and falling for men, there has been a small increase in the number of cases of AIDS positive women. That is of considerable concern. Something like 733 women in Australia are HIV positive; some 133 women have got AIDS; and there have been 73 deaths of women from AIDS. Some 47 per cent of those cases seem to have been contracted through heterosexual sex.

What we have to look at now is the way in which we can increase the education campaign for women so as to make them sure that they hold responsibility for safe sex and that they actually try to practise it themselves. The challenge for many women who felt that they were protected from the likelihood of catching AIDS is that, in light of this evidence, they must face the fact that there is a risk and that the best way for this to be managed is by women taking responsibility for the practice of safe sex.

One of the very important considerations to bear in mind is that women in practising safe contraception, in particular by using the pill, provide no barrier against the transmission of not only AIDS but other sexually transmitted diseases as well. There is some paradox for women in that in looking for contraception guarantees—that is, to insure against getting pregnant—they may inadvertently be putting themselves at risk of getting sexually transmitted diseases. It is one of the areas of education that we must make sure we pass on to young women in Australia.

The program produced by the Family Planning Association certainly deserves commendation. The questionnaire program and interview involved about 1,000 women in four family planning clinics around Australia. There was a 98 per cent response to the questionnaires. It indicates just how seriously the women took this and how well it was carried out by the Family Planning Association. I would like to congratulate the association on producing the report and for the evidence that the women were prepared to share by way of advice and information for the rest of Australia.

Judith Robinson, the chief conductor of this research, said that we have a lot of information in posters on the wall but we have to get that information off the wall and into people's behaviour. Changing behaviour is probably the very hard part of what we must do here. It is no easy matter when we are trying to negotiate safe sex. There is no way women can practise safe sex unless they can negotiate with their partners, particularly if the best barrier—it seems to have been tested as the best barrier—is a condom. The old slogan `If its not on, it's not on' is a very good one, but we have evidence that although people know that, translating it into practice is the challenge ahead for the women of Australia if they want to avoid the spread of AIDS through the heterosexual community. We have a very good reputation in dealing with AIDS; we do not want that good reputation to make us complacent.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. What action is the United Nations taking to rectify the obvious deficiencies in military planning involved in the various peacekeeping missions?

—In the past two years and currently the United Nations has been involved in a record number of peacekeeping activities, most of which have been the result of some very good diplomatic efforts. The obvious weakness that has appeared in the past year or two is that the actual military planning from the United Nations in New York has shown great deficiencies—that is, poor planning and too often decisions changed at a day's notice, et cetera. This is causing enormous angst amongst defence ministers around the globe.

PARA.TAB: In the past three months I have had the opportunity of having discussions with six defence ministers and representatives from at least three or four other major countries, all of whom have expressed great concern at the lack of military planning that has gone into these ventures. The United Nations has set up a working group to look at this, and I know that the United States has produced a major paper. Unless the matter is resolved, the various defence agencies around the world will be far less likely to be involved in peacekeeping in future.

It should be said at the outset that only 28 people in New York are involved in planning these multifaceted operations. They are badly resourced financially and, sadly, intellectually. From time to time we have made loan arrangements for officers to go there. But the fact is that, the way the military works around the globe, there must be planning. If there is a lack of planning and casualties occur, it would be extremely unlikely that, at least, defence ministers and, in turn, their foreign ministers will sign up for these ventures in future. In my view it would be very regrettable if that were ever to occur.

I do not know what the solution is. We have contemplated here that maybe one country should take over on a rotational basis the planning of any particular operation. Senator Gareth Evans and his department are working very hard at the moment on the production of a blue book, which I am sure will tackle this issue, amongst others to do with peacekeeping. Most of that emphasis, of course, will be on heading off the need for peacekeeping activities.

If there is a need for peacekeeping, the requisite amount of planning should be involved. If we do not get it, people will not involve themselves in future. Nothing will kill off peacekeeping ventures more quickly than reckless and unnecessary casualties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a follow-up answer to a question asked by Senator Coulter on 2 September regarding the use of ethanol as an octane enhancer. I am advised by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories that unleaded petrol was introduced in 1986 and sales will exceed those of leaded by 1994. Leaded petrol sales will continue to decline until production is no longer economic in Australia—probably by the year 2002. Therefore, Senator Coulter's estimate of 20 to 25 per cent is probably correct.

PARA.TAB: The Roundtable Conference on Lead in Petrol on 29 July 1993 noted that ethanol can be added to petrol instead of lead without the need for retuning or modification. The Australian Institute of Petroleum has claimed that there are economic and technical disadvantages that outweigh the possible benefits in the short term, including problems in producing and distributing sufficient ethanol, in dealing with water in ethanol and with corrosion. Others are confident these problems are being overcome. The conference expressed support for an urgent study of the use of alternative octane enhancers such as ethanol, and the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency is now organising such a study.

The government is implementing a number of measures that will assist in promoting the use of ethanol as an alternative transport fuel. It has commissioned a feasibility study into the construction of a small scale plant to demonstrate new Australian technologies for producing ethanol from woody fibres and other waste organic material. Following the study, the Commonwealth will provide a grant of $2 million on a dollar-for-dollar basis in partnership with industry for the demonstration project. To encourage the development of alternative transport fuels, including ethanol, the government has committed itself to a five-year guarantee of the current excise free status of alternative transport fuels with at least one year's notice of any intention to change that status. This guarantee will provide the certainty and impetus needed to help ethanol and other alternative fuels become established in the Australian transport sector.

The Energy Research and Development Corporation, in cooperation with a number of other government bodies, has recently commissioned a study of the use of alternative energy sources based on plant biomass, including ethanol. The study will culminate in a strategic plan to develop and deliver energy services and products for use in Australia and for export.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Senate for granting me leave. Like Senator Gareth Evans, I am also conscious of the fact that we should not unnecessarily waste time in this chamber, but I think it does bear some assessment of precisely how the time of this chamber has been used. It is very disappointing that Senator Kernot should put forward a question which seems to be very much in line with the remarks—

TALK.START.PARA: —A dorothy dixer.

—Some could call it a dorothy dixer. But the fact remains that Senator McMullan was well and truly prepared to trot out the Alan Ramsey line. Therefore, I think it is very important that we do understand precisely—
—Is Alan Ramsey wrong?
—He is wrong, and I am surprised that Senator Kernot has not picked up where he has gone wrong. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition, with the support of the Independents, is dragging its feet in the Senate, doing almost nothing except spoiling and haranguing . . . Of that 41 hours only 66 minutes have been devoted to legislation: three minutes in the first week, and 63 minutes on Wednesday night of this week. The rest has all been Opposition flummery.

Even Senator Kernot ought to appreciate that at the start of the new session a whole series of matters have to be dealt with by this chamber to rearrange the business. I am surprised that Senator Kernot swallowed this line—hook, line and sinker. It is precisely that point which is a dramatic overstatement of any problem that has arisen to date, and to the extent that there is a problem it is the responsibility of those on the other side.

PARA.TAB: For example, we have had eight first speeches. There is four hours for a start. Presumably one would not call that opposition flummery. We have had 2 1/2 hours of condolences following the death of Sir Condor Laucke. Again, I would not think one would describe that as opposition flummery. We have had two days of estimates—does the government describe that as opposition flummery? We have had a discussion about the IPU conference, one of the biggest conferences ever organised in this country.

We have also had a very important constitutional debate about the legality of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill containing the extraordinary admission from Senator Gareth Evans that indeed the purpose of the government is precisely what is banned by section 55 of the constitution. In other words, Senator Evans made it plain in this chamber that the government is all about packaging various provisions and various subject matters of taxation that the constitution clearly says one should not package. This is a deliberate flouting of the constitution. That is why it is necessary for that matter to be referred to the legal and constitutional affairs committee. Again, I would not have thought that anyone could seriously stand up in this place and suggest that that sort of debate, which goes to the heart of the legality of the government's budget bills, is somehow to be passed off as opposition flummery.

Registration of interests was again a matter that the government chose to put on the Notice Paper. We have had 2 1/2 hours debate on that. If the government wants to describe its unilateral decision to list that on the Notice Paper ahead of other matters, when this has been around for 10 years, if the government thinks that sort of urgency is something for which we ought to be held responsible, again the government has it fundamentally wrong. We are forced to debate the matters that the government puts on the Notice Paper and that was one of them.

There has also been taking note of answers and a number of other matters, including questions, which is perfectly proper business of the Senate. Unless one is in the business of jackboot democracy—as they seem to be in the House of Representatives where the government no longer believes in the opposition's right to move censure motions and it no longer believe in MPIs. I noted the other day that even Senator McMullan still clings to that quaint notion that somehow question time is a matter of grace and favour on behalf of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—I thought Senator McMullan was agreeing with it the other day. If he has changed his mind, I am delighted to hear it.
—I don't have to change my mind as I have never said it.

—Maybe it was Senator Gareth Evans. These are all very important matters that go to the heart of the conduct of the chamber; they are necessary and, particularly at the start of the sittings, are part and parcel of what the public expects of this chamber. If the government cannot accept that and it cannot then decide what bills are urgent and bring them on when they need to be brought on, then it is the members of the government who are responsible. I hope that the Democrats will appreciate that. Most of all, I hope that Alan Ramsey will understand that there is a bit more to the business of this chamber than the government's inability to list the bills it wants debated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the assumption that Senator Alston's concern with not wasting the time of the Senate is shared by his colleagues, I will be very brief in response in the hope that we will not get the rest of the half hour filled up by other people moving motions to take note.

—I am about to.

—Those opposite are so easy to condescend to. I thank Senator Alston for putting this issue back under public attention, because it is important to reiterate the points I made in my previous answer. I acknowledge that Senator Alston probably could not hear me say, because there was a bit of noise at the time, that there were some five other hours during which we dealt with government business. Although some of that was essential, it was nevertheless a matter at our discretion. That is five hours. Also two hours were spent on business of the Senate which might have been essential: some was but some of it is arguable.

PARA.TAB: However, we were not being ungenerous in our measurement because of the 66 minutes of consideration of legislation, 11 minutes were spent with ministers getting up and introducing bills. TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak, but I have been provoked by Senator McMullan. This is an important matter. This conspiracy between the government and the Democrats to undermine the standing of the Senate does this place no good, and the record ought to be corrected. Senator Kernot believes that she can make some cheap political point out of this matter but in doing so she detrimentally affects the standing of the chamber altogether. We can tell that it is simply a cheap political point by the fact that the question had been given to the minister to answer; the deal had been done.

PARA.TAB: Let us analyse for a second or two exactly what has been happening in this chamber. Do you remember, Mr Deputy President, when we came back a month after the election, what items the government listed to be dealt with first? We basically went for two weeks on the government's initiative: motions concerning the procedure committee reports on the consideration of appropriation bills, motions concerning the powers and functions of parliamentary secretaries, motions concerning the time limits in question time, motions reducing second reading debate speeches to 20 minutes, motions reducing the number of Senate legislative and general purpose standing committees, motions concerning debate on motions relating to answers given to questions without notice, motions relating to quorums, and so on.

That was the priority of this government when we returned after the election—procedural matters that went for a fortnight. It was not surprising that we objected to some matters, like reducing the number for quorums and reducing the time for speeches, because this is the chamber of debate. It is the only chamber of debate in the parliament, particularly given what has happened in the other place in the last few weeks. We objected, and that took some time. In the following two weeks we sat down in a cooperative way—notwithstanding the way we had been treated by the government—and worked through the government's legislative program, sitting late practically every night of the last two weeks of the month so its program was achieved within the one-month sitting time.

What has happened since then? We have come back for three weeks. The first week was budget week and consisted of only three days—needless to say, taken up very much with the budget and matters surrounding the budget. But what was the highest priority of the government during that budget week? It was the register of senators' interests, which the government was determined to push through this place and pursue. It had the highest priority. On the top of the list every day in budget week was that item—not a legislative item, a procedural item.

Then Senator Chamarette brought on her motion on cut-offs. Every frontbencher on the other side got up to debate that, a motion that was simply designed to make the parliamentary process work better. That was the first week. Then we came back for the second week. Two of the four days were taken up with estimates committees, Mr Deputy President—and I remind you that that is part of the legislative process in this place. You cannot take out estimates and say that is not dealing with legislation; that is an integral part of the legislative process.

The third week in this place has been abbreviated to two days. That was not our choice; it is what we were told was to happen. It is not surprising that perhaps not as much government business has, therefore, been transacted as the government might have liked or perhaps as we also would have liked. We are anxious to see the program dealt with properly, in an appropriate order. We have as much interest in that as the government. The government has to learn to manage the show properly. A succession of government managers in this place simply have not been able to get their house in order.

We will cooperate; we say it again. We had one MPI last week. We are not taking up an extraordinary part of the time of this chamber. We will sit down again with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, and, when he comes back from his trip, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Faulkner. We will talk to them about the program and see whether in a cooperative way their program can be put in order so that we can deal with it sensibly. That is what we are prepared to do. Instead of the Democrats and the government conspiring to try to undermine the authority and standing of the Senate, they ought to concentrate on getting their program in order and then everyone would be better off.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the additional answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter on 2 September 1993 relating to petrol.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I am pleased that Senator Schacht has informed himself on the question of the addition of alcohol to petrol as an octane enhancer and as a way in which we could completely eliminate lead from petrol. In his answer today he observed that if we follow the course on which we are now embarked, lead will not be removed from petrol before the year 2002 and that by then production will no longer be economic. I am quite sure that even then, in 2002, there will still be some people driving older cars that will need to use some octane enhancer. I just want to pick up two points with respect to Senator Schacht's otherwise excellent answer. Firstly, he said:

The Australian Institute of Petroleum has claimed that there are economic and technical disadvantages that outweigh the possible benefits in the short term, including problems in producing and distributing sufficient ethanol, in dealing with water in ethanol and with corrosion.

Of course, one should not be surprised that the Australian Institute of Petroleum should be averse to the replacement of roughly 10 per cent of the fuel, which it currently imports and sells, with a different source of fuel. It has very much a vested interest in selling as much petroleum as it possibly can. Senator Schacht needs to deal with those claims from that quarter with a certain degree of circumspection.

PARA.TAB: I note that when Manildra, a company in the south east of New South Wales, produced a large amount of ethanol from wheat starch and sought to put that into ethanol, the manager of that company approached one of the oil companies to see whether it would take the ethanol on board and use it as a fuel. The oil company said that it would get back to him. When he approached two other oil companies it became clear to him that the first oil company had already approached the other two and that they were intent on blocking the use of ethanol as an addition to fuel.

The manager then went ahead and actually bought a service station and proceeded to offer the ethanol petrol mix to the public, whereupon the remaining major supplier of petrol undertook to buy as much ethanol as he could produce. That gasohol mixture is now being sold exclusively—it is the only fuel which is sold—in six service stations in southern New South Wales. They are doing very well out of it and the petrol company is continuing to sell that mix.

Senator Schacht mentioned—and I am pleased to note this—that the government has offered $2 million for the development of a plant to make ethanol out of cellulosic wastes. That grant will be matched dollar for dollar—so the amount will be $4 million. The technology to do that is already quite well advanced. This raises one of the other very significant arguments which have been brought against the use of ethanol—namely, the energy required to actually make the ethanol available.

The technology which is being developed involves the separation of the ethanol from dilute fermentation mashes without the use of distillation. It involves a method of preparation which not only separates the ethanol but also provides in floccular form the cellulosic wastes which are left over. These can then be used as a fuel which can reconcentrate the solutions which are used in the extraction. So it is a totally energy self-sufficient process. I think that other objection to the use of ethanol, which the minister did not mention, has already been addressed and has been overcome. So again I would press the government to go ahead with this as quickly as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1.Optometry has been covered by Medicare since its inception in 1975, and currently provides eye care to over 2.4 million people each year.
2.Removal of optometric benefits from Medicare will increase Government expenditure on eye care, as people will instead obtain their care from a more expensive source.

3.The cost to the public of eye care will increase, both through the removal of benefits for optometric consultations and the shift to ophthalmologists who generally charge well over the schedule fee.

4.The visual welfare of the community will suffer as people are discouraged from seeking eye care. Many eye diseases, such as glaucoma, do not produce symptoms until they are in an advanced stage. Any discouragement from seeking regular eye care will increase suffering from these diseases.
5.The removal of benefits for optometric examinations will disadvantage children, as undetected visual disorders will adversely affect their development and school performance.
6.Access to eye care will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, as part-time and visiting optometric practices will no longer be economically viable, and alternate care is not available.
We therefore request that the Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations by optometrists are covered.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The urgent need for the government to ensure the continuing viability of the wine industry as a developing exporter by abandoning its plan to increase the sales tax on wine by 55 per cent

The wine industry is a particularly South Australian industry, but it is contributed to very substantially by Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia, Tasmania and even the Northern Territory, the ACT and Queensland. I have been to wineries in nearly all of these states and have enjoyed some of their produce. This industry is not peculiarly a South Australian industry; as I say, it is an Australian one.

PARA.TAB: It has one other very special characteristic at the moment: compared with just about any other Australian industry, it is enjoying the most phenomenal increase in exports. For those who are not familiar with the details, I will provide some. In 1986 Australia exported 10 million litres of wine. In 1993 it has jumped to 103 million litres. The value of those exports in 1986 was $20 million. The value of those exports in 1993 is $289 million. As people like my colleague Senator Ferguson, who is here today, will tell you, that is one of the most dramatic increases in exports of any industry in Australia. Coming from South Australia, as does Senator Ferguson, I cannot resist saying that this was particularly contributed to by my state.

Three-quarters of Australian wine is currently consumed on the domestic market. That should tell us that this massive move into exports has been perhaps the greatest public relations exercise for Australian industry that has ever been undertaken. It does not matter how much someone increases their exports in, for example, furniture. That is not going to go on every table around the globe. If someone increases exports in some sort of computer software, that is a very valuable sort of thing but it is not a public relations exercise that reaches the tables of individual people around the globe. What we have here is a fantastic public relations exercise. People can buy a little bit of Australia, take it home, put it on the table and enjoy it with their meal. If you like, bottled wine represents the spirit of Australia that one can purchase at the local wine store.

With this phenomenal export increase, we find that those opposite want to increase the sales tax on this industry by 55 per cent; they want to jump it up from 20 per cent to 31 per cent without warning. Senator Sherry, who is not here, is the next speaker in this debate. He was telling this chamber the other day that he had consultations on this matter with the industry before and after the budget. I hope he takes the opportunity in his speech to tell us whom exactly he did consult with about this increase prior to the budget. The information the industry has which has been passed on to us is that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) found out about this increase being imposed at 6 o'clock on budget night.

Senator Sherry has just graced the chamber with his presence. I welcome him and invite him in his speech to list the winegrowers that he consulted with, the industry people that he personally consulted with, about this increase prior to the budget. That is what he is on record as saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not about this increase.

—Yes, indeed. We will check the Hansard on that. It has already been checked. I am not going to debate the matter with Senator Sherry at this time. I put that request to him. He has already signalled an intention to worm out of what he said the other day.

PARA.TAB: If the government does not want to listen to what people on this side of the chamber have to say about the devastating effect that this tax increase will have on exports, I think we could turn to the Premier of South Australia—one of the last Labor premiers. He will not be there for much longer if Senator Ferguson and other South Australian senators have their way. If all South Australians had their way, he would be gone by now—if he had the guts to call an election. He turned the State Bank into a disaster. He turned the entire state into a disaster. Desperately clinging to power, he finally came to his senses and thought, `I have been sent down the chute by my federal colleagues. They do not care what happens in South Australia'. In relation to the most recent study on this matter which was released in South Australia last week, the Premier of South Australia, Mr Arnold, said that the study made it clear the federal government had made the wrong decision.

I say to Senator Sherry that the Labor premier of South Australia is telling the Labor federal government that it has made a mistake. This is what it really comes down to. Who is the government going to listen to? I do not mind if it does not listen to us, it never does. That is why the country is in such a mess. Perhaps it should listen to Premier Arnold. He is, after all, one of theirs. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The results confirm our concerns—
that presumably means the entire Labor Party in South Australia; I will come back to that point—
that the Federal Government will not gain income from the move, rather it will cause serious disruption and downturn in an industry just beginning to make its impact on our export horizon.

I presume `our concerns' means the concerns of the Labor Party in South Australia. But when I look over at those empty benches, even if I can imagine a South Australian senator sitting there, I cannot imagine that senator crossing this floor to support us, to support the Democrats who I understand will support this tax not being imposed—albeit with a caveat on it for 12 months—and to support, possibly, the Greens. If that is what the South Australian Labor Party thinks, let us see the South Australian Labor senators put their money where their mouths are.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are not here.

—Yes, they are not here. As my colleague Senator Ferguson interjected a moment ago, the reason Senator Sherry does not give a tuppence halfpenny about what the Premier of South Australia said is that, federally, the government has given South Australia away—and so it should; it is such a disaster and Premier Arnold has made such an absolutely irretrievable mess.

PARA.TAB: If the government does not want to listen to what we say about an investment decline, it might like to look at an independent report which will be released this afternoon by KPMG Peat Marwick showing that investment decisions in this industry—the industry that has had such a dramatic export increase—will decrease by $400 million to $500 million. A massive export drive in the wine industry cannot be funded unless it is coupled with a successful investment program. We just cannot produce more grapes from the same acreage every year; we have to have more plantings, more equipment and more vats—the lot.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's true. We will accept that.

—With the greatest of respect, what Senator Sherry's government has been saying since the election and during the election would not be an indication that it knows what true is. We will see a reduction in investment of $400 million to $500 million—a downturn in investment of half a billion dollars. If for some reason the government does not like KPMG Peat Marwick, it can turn to the Elton Mayo School of Management in South Australia which has put out a paper entitled `The adverse effect of increased wholesale sales tax on the competitive advantage of the Australian wine industry'. It has three things to say that I would like to mention. First:

SPEECH.PARA: It is now well accepted that domestic market conditions can have a substantial impact on the international competitiveness of an industry.

We accept that. Most of us have read good parts, if not all, of Michael Porter's book. Someone on the government side has probably given members of the government a briefing of some sort. Senator Sherry would do well to acquire a copy for himself. The second point made by the Elton Mayo School of Management study is:
There is little doubt that reduced profitability and potential for profitability will result in scaled down investments in new vineyards and winery up-grades.

So it is not looking too good at that point. The two points made are: firstly, that the domestic market does impact on the capacity to export; and, secondly, this change will produce an investment downfall. The third point is probably the most important point—the point that the wine industry says the government just does not understand. It is:
. . . the Australian wine industry's competitive advantage is neither as secure or as strong as some would wish.
It is a fragile export market that we are exporting into. I commend the study by Byron Sharp to anybody who would like to read it.

PARA.TAB: That brings me to today's article in the Sydney Morning Herald by Ross Gittins, reproduced in the Age. Mr Gittins basically says, `This is a con by the wine industry. It doesn't deserve to be saved from this tax. It has managed to increase exports under increased taxes before and it follows that it will be able to do it again'. With the greatest of respect to Mr Gittins, that argument is like the one run by the chicken when there were 20 chickens in the yard. Every time the farmer came in and took another chicken, the chicken said, `See, he proves it every time; he doesn't want to cut off my head'. He kept saying that until he was the last chicken in the yard. That is what Mr Gittins is doing; he is saying, `It has all worked before; it follows that it will continue to work'. It does not follow like that at all. The industry has tried its very best. It has burnt the midnight oil to accommodate the cost increases that came with an increase in sales tax in 1986—another unannounced increase in sales tax, which I had the pleasure of voting against at the time.

The wine industry has accommodated that increase. Its members have done their best to say, `If this tax has to be doubled'—as it was in 1986—`we will take it in our stride, we will overcome that difficulty and we will nonetheless achieve'. They have done that, and their reward for that effort from this government—from Senator Sherry and his colleagues—is a 55 per cent increase in the tax yet again.

I recommend to Mr Gittins and others who do not understand the fragility of the market we are moving into at such a rapid pace an article which is soon to be released in a wine magazine by the editor of that magazine and of Wine and Spirit International called Robert Joseph. Robert Joseph will explain to senators opposite, if they care to read the article, the fragility of the market into which Australian wine goes.

It is a very sensitive market on two aspects—it is very sensitive on price and it is very sensitive on quality. Our reputation with respect to quality is almost second to none. We can produce better wines than the French. There is no doubt about that; we can do it, and we do it, with some regularity. We do not always do it, but neither do the French—I have drunk some pretty dreadful French wines in my life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now the truth is coming out. You have been drinking French plonk.

—Not too much. Some people keep a narrow focus in their life and can never put things in perspective to see what they are competing with. As Senator Sherry well knows, those who do not understand their competition will never get anywhere. That is how the wine industry in Australia has done well—by sending people away to study overseas and take every bit of skill and ingenuity that is overseas and bring it back here to add to ours. There is no shame in the industry doing that, and there is no shame in anyone tasting imported wine—quite the contrary, the more informed Australian consumers are, the more they will realise how good Australian wine is. I encourage Australians to buy a bottle of overseas plonk. They will pretty soon rush back to the local product.

PARA.TAB: We are exporting into a fragile market. Senator Sherry will undoubtedly want to say, `This is going to affect the domestic market; there will be a domestic market downturn.' Of course there will. What does he think happens from that? Investors will be scared off. Who, with a large amount of money to invest, will invest in an industry where 75 per cent of its sales area suffers a dramatic decline because of government intervention through an increased sales tax?

The government admits that there will be some downfall in the domestic market. We could argue until the cows come home what percentage it will be. The crucial point is that the truth of the matter is that when there is a downturn in the domestic wine industry market, investment in the wine industry is reduced. There is no way that the industry can go on with its planned dramatic increase in exports unless it has that investment. The regional impact on grape growers and small wineries is that they will be put out of business, especially in my state but in some other regions as well.

Why, one might ask, pick on the wine industry as opposed to the beer or spirit industries? I notice that Mr Gittins made some comment about this in his article. Whenever it is desperate, Labor drags out the equality issue and says, `Why should wine be treated any differently?'. There is every reason why it should be treated differently—it has been a responsible industry all along. The wine industry started the `Drink in Moderation' campaign. That campaign has been very effective. The wine industry is a responsible industry and does not deserve to be treated the same as others which, perhaps, in the past have not been as responsible.

I note a survey done in 1989, and I do not know that our drinking patterns have changed that dramatically since then. It showed that, yes, more people drink wine than beer on a reasonably regular basis—that is true—but the percentage of those who drink at heavy or very heavy levels is dramatically higher for beer drinkers. Ask members of the medical profession whether the problem with alcohol abuse lies primarily with beer or wine and, if they are informed and honest, they will say that it lies primarily with beer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Senator Sherry says `rubbish'. I look forward to Senator Sherry, in his speech, drawing our attention to the statistics he relies on to show that what I have said is not the case.

PARA.TAB: The wine industry has tried to do its best. It has tried to work with government and industry together investing in research and education. It has taken a socially responsible attitude towards the amelioration of alcohol abuse. It has worked as a team. When industry members are overseas, they work together. You do not see Orlando arguing with Penfolds arguing with someone else. They work as a team overseas to generically promote Australian wine and, they would argue, Australia.

The nature of this industry is not like the beer industry, which is basically made up of international beer barons. Sure, there are the big four wine producers—no-one denies that—but there are 600 small winemakers and 5,000 independent growers, and these are the people who will be affected by this tax increase. Six hundred small winemakers, all employing a number of people and paying for some packaging, printing, labelling and bottling; and 5,000 independent growers. Basically, they are family operations, but nonetheless they employ people.

If this tax increase goes ahead, the domestic market will take a dramatic downturn, which will cause a rush of new investment to other places—that is, it will put a stop to new investment in the wine industry, and that will put a stop to the export push.

TALK.START.PARA: —And jobs.

—And jobs. The reduction in quantity at the domestic level, which the industry may or may not be able to handle in one sense, means that its total costs will go up. For the same costs, it will be producing less for the domestic market. That means that some may be encouraged into some sort of quality degradation to keep up with their export demand; they will cover costs by slightly lessening quality here and there. That is why the article that is about to be released by the editor of that wine magazine and Wine and Spirit International is important. We cannot afford to have the domestic producers, who also export, trying to pass on any of the costs or absorbing the cost by quality reduction in the export market. If that happens, there will be a very dramatic loss to Australia in exports and, at the very least, an absolute full stop to the dramatic export drive being undertaken by this industry.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I remind Senator Sherry that I want to hear with whom he consulted prior to the budget. He told us the other day that he consulted on this matter of the wine tax increase, or did he mislead the Senate? He does not have too many planks to walk down. He has to choose between one or the other. I look forward to hearing that argument. I look forward to hearing him tell us how his government plans to support the wine industry and how he thinks it can possibly be saved in its massive export drive, if this increase is permitted to go ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take up a number of points in this debate. Firstly, I will deal with the contents of the motion and the way it is worded—it refers to a 55 per cent increase in the tax level on wine. Secondly, I will refer to the supposed reduction in wine sales and, in fact, all alcohol sales over various periods in the last decade. Thirdly, I will refer to some issues relating to investment. Fourthly, I will refer to some issues relating to jobs. I will also touch on the devaluation of the Australian dollar, which is relevant in this debate. Before doing that, I will respond to some of the comments made by Senator Vanstone.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, Senator Vanstone referred to the attitude of the Premier of South Australia, Mr Arnold, and his position in opposing this tax. The Premier of South Australia represents a constituency in South Australia. This parliament represents a national constituency. It comes as no surprise to me that the Premier of South Australia is opposed to the increase in sales tax. Last year, when we had a debate on resource security in the Tasmanian context, the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Groom, berated Tasmanian Liberal senators for not crossing the floor on the issue of resource security.

Premiers represent their own constituency. It is a more limited constituency than a national government, and rightly so. It comes as no great surprise to me or anyone else on this side that premiers represent their constituency against the interests of their national government, even when that national government is of the same political colour. There have been many examples of that.

The second point that Senator Vanstone raises is the issue of why the South Australian Labor senators are not here to listen to this debate. There are only two South Australian senators on the other side of the chamber; where are the rest of them? If members of the public are listening to this debate I want them to understand that the norm in all parliamentary debates in this place is that it is very rare for all senators to be in the chamber, and extremely rare for all senators from one state to be here, even if the issue has some particular importance to that state. There are only two South Australian Liberal senators in the chamber and I ask Senator Vanstone: where are the rest of them? They are not here.

In her speech Senator Vanstone admitted that she drinks French wine. Frankly, I would not drink the crap, because it is crap. I think it is an amazing—
