Let us not pretend that we have a knight in shining armour in the wine industry, which is massively dominated by small producers, versus these big beer barons, because that is not the fact of life. The fact of life is that it is dominated by oligopolies.

I turn to the central elements in this debate. Firstly, the reference to a 55 per cent increase in sales tax. As I said on a previous occasion, the tax is being increased from 20 per cent to 31 per cent. It is important to understand what the final effect is on the retail price of a bottle of wine or a cask of wine. The opposition keeps giving the impression that the final price will go up by 55 per cent; that is not correct. The price of a $10 bottle of wine is estimated to go up by between $1 and $1.50 retail. The price of a $20 bottle of wine is estimated to go up by between $1.50 and $2. At the end of the day, it is nothing like a 55 per cent increase in the final price of the retail product.

I will deal with the effects of previous changes to the taxation on wine and, generally, alcohol. The opposition tends to distinguish between wine and beer, and the effects of taxation on wine and ignore beer. Domestic sales of wine grew from 320 million litres in 1984-85 to 331 million litres in 1987-88. Sales declined gradually, after the 1988-89 budget tax cuts on low alcohol beer, to a floor of 296 million litres in 1990-91. Domestic sales of wine have since recovered to reach 315 million litres in 1991-92 and 312 million litres in 1992-93, and I suggest that the slight decrease last year had something to do with the recession.

The per capita consumption of wine, beer and spirits has also been falling over the last 10 years, at the expense of a rising soft drink consumption. I think that should tell us all—if we are not too affected by what we had to drink at lunch time—that there is a general decline in the consumption of alcoholic beverages at the expense of non-alcoholic beverages and low alcohol beverages, particularly beer. In fact, full strength beer consumption fell by 22 1/2 per cent over the last decade, whereas light beer consumption increased. I think that does put the statistics in some sort of context.

The third issue I want to mention is investment. The argument of those opposite is that we need a profitable, strong domestic market in order to expand and obtain capital in order to obtain the investment to export. As I said earlier, in the wine industry 80 to 90 per cent of Australia's production is dominated by four large companies. It is very similar to the beer industry in that respect.

The interesting issue is that those four large wine companies do lead the export drive, as Senator Vanstone has admitted. They have not had a great deal of difficulty in attracting investment. Since the budget BRL Hardy announced it would outline a three-year $75 million vineyard development program within the next few months. South Australian Brewing announced that its wine division, not its beer division, would benefit from $100 to $150 million of capital expenditure planned for the next few years. This is all post budget.

We have been challenged to indicate what the government is doing. There are a number of positive initiatives in this budget. The government is reducing the corporate tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. It is introducing a 10 per cent general investment allowance to address the run-down in capital equipment in agriculture. This will also assist the wine industry because the production of wine is in part an agricultural production.

This leads me to the next issue of jobs. I think most members of the Senate would have received a copy of the document entitled `Impact of wholesale sales tax on wine: 1993 Budget' from the South Australian Centre for Economic Studies. This is supposedly a document which should support opposition to the increase in the wholesale sales tax on wine.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly does.
—If one looks at the executive summary, one will see some interesting aspects, which are expanded in greater detail. The opposition is making—
—Have you read the whole thing?

—I have read the document. The opposition is making a great deal of the alleged reduction in jobs in the wine industry that will flow from this tax measure. That is nothing new. In fact, this document boasts about job reductions over the past 10 years. The executive summary states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . cost efficiencies in the production of Australian wine that have been obtained through major rationalisations amongst wine companies.

It may surprise the opposition to know that these major rationalisations amongst wine companies over the past 10 years in order to make themselves more efficient, in order to boost investment, in order to introduce new technology and in order to improve productivity, have meant the loss of hundreds of jobs in the wine industry. So job loss in this industry is nothing new. Frankly, it is to be expected. The opposition is claiming that further job reductions will occur over the next five, 10 or however many years we care to look at. There will be further job reductions, but they will not be because of this tax measure; they will be because the investment and the rationalisation in this industry will continue to go on as they have over the past 10 years. It is totally dishonest for the opposition to claim that job losses are the result of the wine tax when they are not. They are the result of an ongoing rationalisation in the industry which is occurring anyway. That is stated on the second page of the executive summary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say that you had read it?

—I know that Senator Vanstone does not like hearing the truth about this issue. That deals with the issue of jobs and employment. The other issue in this document—and it is quite interesting that no-one opposite has yet mentioned it—is the devaluation of the Australian dollar. It is one of the factors to which the industry attributes the important expansion of the wine industry over the past 10 years. I put on record the fact that the industry has done a very good job. It has exported; it has successfully sold its product overseas—with some help from the Australian government in the form of research dollars, marketing dollars, et cetera. The industry has done a very good job, but it does acknowledge the devaluation of the Australian dollar relative to the currencies of other wine producing countries since 1985. It is nice to hear that the devaluation has been of some assistance to the export value of Australian wine. We have only to look at the devaluation of the Australian dollar in the last week or two. The return to wine exporters has improved because of that devaluation. That will be a major stimulus for the export of wine. That is a point made in the executive summary of this document to which Senator Vanstone referred in her speech.

PARA.TAB: What are the motivations of those opposite? The Liberal-National parties have adopted the populist cause of opposing all tax increases. That is the course it has set. But it is not a responsible course. We have to govern this country and we have to strike as nearly balanced a budget as we can. We have no suggestions from those opposite about how to replace the revenue lost if this measure is defeated.

The Australian Democrats have put up some suggestions; I will give Senator Spindler that. But this irresponsible opposition has not put up any solution to the revenue loss whatsoever. I turn to the Democrats because I have to give them a bit of a swipe. I do not think we should let them off free in this debate. The Democrats have been holier than thou in this whole debate and in budget negotiations over the past few years; they proclaim purity and say they are acting on economic responsibility. But when it comes to the crunch they are reduced to populism like the opposition, the Liberal-National party, is.

The Democrats' position is actually more dishonest than that of the Liberal-National party. At least the Liberal-National party's theme is consistent. It is consistently wrong, but at least it is consistent, unlike the Democrats. The Democrats come in here and say, `We are pure. We are holier than thou. We are responsible'. But when a tax increase threatens their political base in South Australia, they are no different from the rest of us. I have heard the comments coming from Senator Lees and Senator Spindler. One would think they drank wine for breakfast, dinner and tea; in fact, the opposition thinks they do. But the Democrats are reduced to populism like the rest of those opposite. I think the Democrats' position on this proposed tax increase is totally irresponsible. It shows that they are reduced to political opportunism like the rest of those opposite. They are the motives of the Liberal-National party and the Democrats. I feel a little sad having to give the Democrats a bit more stick than the Liberal-National party, but on this occasion I think it is warranted.

Senator Vanstone started her contribution by referring to the comments of Lynn Arnold, the Premier of South Australia. As I said, it is not a surprise. The Premier of South Australia is there to represent his political interests and we have had this occur before. But this government is here to represent the interests of Australia as a whole. We will be striving to reduce the deficit in the budget to as low an amount as we can over the next four years—to about one to 1.2 per cent of gross domestic product. Unfortunately, some increased tax measures are necessary in that package. We do not resile from that because that is the responsible way to do it. Therefore, Lynn Arnold's position comes as no surprise.

If the opposition, the Liberal-National party—I do not refer to the Democrats here—were responsible, then it would be looking at ways in which we could be reducing the budget deficit over the next four years. It has cast aside its goods and services tax. What has it replaced it with? A great big question mark. It cannot have a balanced budget and it has to come up with a solution to that problem before the next election. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order under standing order 191. I seek very briefly, without taking the debate over its two-hour time limit or cutting too deeply into anybody else's time, to make an explanation of some remarks I made, because I believe they were either misquoted or misunderstood—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—You claim you were misquoted or misunderstood?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do.
—Proceed, Senator Vanstone.

—I could speak for about half an hour on this matter because there were so many aspects that were misquoted or misunderstood. But there is one particular one I want to draw attention to. I said in my speech—and I am happy to repeat the point—that we do make the best wine. On numerous occasions we have beaten the French, quite happily. They have been regarded internationally, right up to the last decade or so, as being the producers of the best wine, and we have beaten them on a number of occasions. I then went on to say that we do not always make the best wine, but neither do the French. I added that I have tasted some pretty dreadful French wine in my time. That was jumped on by Senator Sherry, who likes to participate in debate at a certain infantile level. I invite those who are listening, and those insomniacs who read the Hansard late at night, to reflect on what I said and what Senator Sherry attempted to turn that into by misquoting. He said that a senator for South Australia, the wine state, came in here to defend the French wine industry. That is clearly not the case. It is not possible for me to say that it is a disgraceful exercise or that Senator Sherry was lying. So I do not say that. I ask people to judge—
—You are sailing very close to the wind. I would remind you that this is not to be debated.

—I will not go any further to the wind in that respect other than to invite people to look at Senator Sherry's speech, compare it with what I actually did say and ask themselves what that tells them about his intellectual capacity and his contribution to this debate.

—The Senate is debating the urgent need for the government to ensure the continuing viability of the wine industry by deferring, or certainly not proceeding with this year, the increase in sales tax on wine from 20 per cent to 31 per cent. Before I deal with the substantive arguments, I would like to point out to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) that the Australian Democrats have been thoroughly consistent on this issue rather than, as he claimed, inconsistent. We have voted against the previous attempts of the government to impose a wine tax, the latest being in 1986 when the opposition—with one exception; that of Senator Vanstone—voted for the increase in the tax on wine. While Senator Vanstone's action was very honourable, it did not carry sufficient weight to move the opposition to join with the Democrats to stop this pernicious tax on one of the most effective growth industries that Australia has.

PARA.TAB: Our objection was then, and is now, that this tax is being imposed as a revenue raiser without any consideration of the effect it will have on the industry, without regard for the economic and social consequences, and without any regard as to how it fits into an industry plan for this or any other industry. The truth is that this government does not have a positive, constructive, strategic industry policy.

As I have said before, the Australian wine industry is one of the success stories in Australia's industrial development. We are told that Australia's economic salvation lies in exports and I would like to refer to that aspect of the wine industry. Exports have increased from around 40 million litres in 1988-89 to 103 million litres in 1992-93. In real terms, wine exports increased by 130 per cent in that period. In 1992-93 the value of production in Australian dollars was $289 million. But the growth of the industry is exponential. The annual volume is expected to reach $1 billion by the year 2000.

However, exports are only a small part of the wine production in this country. The domestic market takes three-quarters of the wine production. Australia is still a small producer in world terms, taking something like two per cent of world production and trade. Our inroads into overseas markets therefore are dependent not only on acknowledged excellent quality—and I would say it is much better than French or other overseas wines—but also on the cost of production.

It is a matter of record that the cost of production has been lowered in recent years to put the industry on a highly competitive basis. I would remind Senator Sherry that that merely places the industry in a better position to employ more people in the future, as the projections for the year 2000 clearly show. It is also quite clear that in the last few years the industry has been assisted by the progressive devaluation of the Australian dollar. In many ways this argument—and a lot of weight was placed on it by Senator Sherry—does not alter the basic proposition that this tax has been imposed on an industry without consultation and without consideration of its effects on production right here and now or on the development of this industry in the next few years.

It is a matter of record that the growing of premium grapes has increased from 36 per cent in 1985-86 to 44 per cent in 1986-87. It is also a matter of record that export wines predominantly use premium grapes, whereas domestic consumption is mainly based on non-premium grapes. We know that about 72 per cent of domestic sales are in casks and flagons, which clearly identifies the quality level of these sales. The important point to be made about these figures is that the two markets are not readily interchangeable. It may have been expected by the government—and clearly the government has not considered this carefully—that wine produced from grapes grown for the domestic market, the demand for which will inevitably decline if this tax is imposed, can be switched to the international market. Clearly, that will not be possible.

Make no mistake about it: demand for wine will certainly decrease. When the 20 per cent sales tax on wine was introduced in 1986, against the opposition of the Democrats and with the support of the Liberal and National party coalition, per capita consumption decreased from 22 litres to 18 litres in 1990-91, a decline of almost 20 per cent. It took another year to show a slight increase to 19 litres per capita in 1991-92. The proposed increase in sales tax by 11 per cent will translate into a price increase of 9.1 per cent, which in turn will translate into a medium-to long-term decrease in demand of 12.7 per cent, according to research commissioned by the South Australian government and carried out by the South Australian Centre for Economic Studies.

As I have said before, it is quite clear that investment in the wine industry is not mobile. To establish a vineyard one needs to find and select suitable land; engage in thorough site preparation; and arrange water supply or irrigation. There are at least three years between planting and the first harvest of grapes, and between seven and 10 years before one can expect the vines to reach their full potential. We have a situation in which wine growers will find that their product is no longer acceptable on the domestic market and that their grapes are not suitable for export wine because they are not premium grapes. What are these wine growers to do? Should they pull up their vines? Should they perhaps hope that at some future stage they will be able to replant with vines that produce premium grapes? If growers did pull up their vines—and I believe that would be a logical consequence—the devastation would be worse than the phylloxera which devastated vineyards in the 1870s in Victoria. Wine growers could be excused if they christened our Prime Minister `Phylloxera Paul'.

The growth of the industry is reflected in the growth of wineries: in 1982 there were 301; in 1993 there are 739, of which 230 are in my home state of Victoria. There are also 3,512 agricultural producers whose main product is grapes, most of which are supplied to wineries.

The wine industry, however, does not only produce wine; it is also a very positive source of tourism traffic. Only today the visiting German President, President Weizsacker, said that he has visited with great pleasure the vineyard regions in South Australia and Victoria.

We should also consider the social aspects of the more than 3,000 enterprises growing wines and over 700 wineries. We find that 90 per cent of these are family farms; 85 per cent of these are smaller than 50 hectares. At least 300 of these growers will go to the wall. If this measure is instituted, it will affect hundreds of families and thousands of people, and further thousands of people living and working in the communities where these vineyards are situated.

It will also affect a most important ingredient—confidence. I refer to confidence in the future of their industry, confidence in their government which could make such a decision on the basis of the still very scant information, a decision which will jeopardise the future of one of Australia's most promising industries. And here is the nub of the argument: the decision was made as a revenue raiser and obviously without consideration of the factors which determine the industry's success or failure. In that, it follows the miserable tradition of the tariff cutting regime—sink or swim. Many industries sank to the tune of at least 200,000 job losses, bringing the total to a million Australians on the scrap heap.

With this government measure we have another example of that tradition. Someone in Finance or Treasury saw a disparity in government revenue between the rate imposed on beer and the rate imposed on wine and forgot to look at the large scale manufacturing beer brewing industry able to sell its products on a cash basis virtually as soon as they leave the assembly line, and the winegrower and vintner, the many small producers who are labour intensive and who require time for storage and skilful marketing in the home market and, more particularly, overseas. So we have a total disregard of the character of this industry, of its potential and of its future.

The Australian Democrats reject totally this ad hoc, marauding approach to industry policy. It is clear that the Australian Government is not prepared to construct and pursue a considered, goal directed industry policy in the wine industry or in any other industry. We believe that this must change. The Democrats' concept of a positive industry policy is for the government to consult with producers and workers in each industry sector and to balance this with independent objective research to maximise the capacity of the industry, to lift its productive capacity, to enable it to compete against imports in the domestic market and against all comers in the international arena.

It is for this reason that the Democrats will vote against the imposition of the additional 11 per cent sales tax on wine this year, and this is why we are prepared to have another look at the matter at the end of this financial year, when this consultation has been done, when this research, including by the regional development task force, has been completed, and when the effect of various levels of taxation on the future of the industry has been clearly established. More importantly, we will combine this with an assessment of what needs to be done not just to maintain but to increase the viability of the Australian wine industry. I confirm and repeat that we will vote against the wine tax to be imposed by this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Vanstone's motion that, in the opinion of the Senate, the wine tax is a matter of urgency. Firstly, I would like to make some remarks on some of the comments made by Senator Sherry, who appears to be in some doubt about who exactly he was elected to represent. I am in no doubt about who I was elected to represent—and that is the people of Victoria, who include winegrowers, vineyard owners and the people who work in them, regardless of their political persuasion. No doubt some of them voted for the party represented by Senator Sherry, in which case they will have been thoroughly disillusioned.
—We'll look forward to seeing you cross the floor over the next six years.

—Speaking of crossing the floor, I am sure that Senator Sherry will be interested in the comments made by his compatriot Peter Cleeland, the federal member for McEwan, who perhaps is contemplating this very measure. Last Sunday he issued a press release saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . all we [the government] have done is penalise wine producers for their efforts by increasing the tax on wine. I believe the domestic base of the industry should be protected to allow producers to reinvest in exports . . . The simple fact is that an increase in prices caused by taxes will cause a reduction in domestic sales. I would have thought—
and this is a member of the government speaking—
that the Government in its export drive would have done all that it could to assist an increase in those exports. Wine is a major new export for Australia and should in my view be encouraged.

I am sure that his colleagues, Silvia Smith and Mr Bilney, who also come from wine producing areas, will be very interested in his comments. If they did cross the floor and vote against this measure, it would be possible for it to be killed stone-dead. I would say that there is considerable disquiet in government ranks over this wine tax. Premier Arnold, at least, had the courage to speak out for his constituents, and we should speak out for ours.

PARA.TAB: Tax, as such, is an increased amount payable to government, and that means an increased cost of production to wineries. The South Australian Centre for Economic Studies, as Senator Spindler indicated, showed that there would be results in the retail price increase of at least nine per cent. It is through the production of wine from non-premium grape varieties for the domestic market that significant economies of scale can be obtained in production and packaging that enable Australian wine to be produced at a competitive cost on world markets.

If domestic sales fall—and they will with an increase of nine per cent in retail prices—effects on the industry will be significant. Economies of scale obtained in production and packaging enabling Australian wine to be produced at a competitive cost on world markets will no longer apply because profits from the burgeoning domestic sector will not be applicable. Overseas consumers, notably in the UK, where we export 44 per cent of our wine, look at wine critically when it is before them on the supermarket shelves. They have a choice of US, French and Australian wine and they will buy the wine that suits their pockets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly.

—Senator Sherry should listen to what I am saying. This argument goes on and has a logical conclusion. Up till now, Australian wines have been presented at a realistic cost. Over 90 per cent of Australian wine sold in the UK sells for between 300 and 500 pence per bottle. Less than five per cent of Australian wine is sold for over 500 pence per bottle. There is a limited room for the margins to be squeezed before the market ceases to be profitable. Therefore, if domestic sales are reduced there will a limited margin for Australian wine exporters to send their wine overseas.

PARA.TAB: As cited by Senator Spindler, there were 301 wineries in Australia in 1982, increasing to 739 wineries by 1993. Even with some cross ownership, there are seven major producers and a proliferation of smaller producers. Given the higher production costs associated with the smaller levels of production, smaller wineries have to market their wine very competitively. With an estimated 16 per cent increase in winery costs as a result of this tax measure, they will need to be very competitive indeed.

As a result of the increase in sales tax, the South Australian Centre for Economic Studies that I referred to earlier estimates that these small wineries will experience a 3.6 per cent decline in sales in the short term and up to 11.8 per cent in the long term, assuming that the full increase in sales tax is passed on to consumers. For many small wineries, such a decline in sales will be unsustainable in the long run.

It is not only the effect on wineries that we need to contemplate; it is the effect on the surrounding areas. Tourism in such areas as the Clare Valley, the Barossa Valley and the McLaren Vale regions in South Australia, as Senator Vanstone has detailed, will be badly affected. I would also like to include in this from my own state of Victoria the Pyrenees, the Yarra Valley, the north east of Victoria, the Geelong area and central Victoria.

Employment in these areas is particularly important. Casual seasonal work provides additional income for rural families. At a time when many farm incomes are at a zero or negative level, the working vineyards and wineries give rural people, particularly women—and I will detail this more in a moment—a chance to make extra income for their families. Wine is one of the few growth areas in rural Australia at the moment and it deserves every encouragement. Given the government's avowed commitment to jobs, and particularly its supposed commitment to maintaining and improving employment opportunities for women, I believe that the regressive nature of the increase in the wholesale sales tax is immediately apparent.

I would now like to examine in reasonable detail the operation of a small winery in my home area of Victoria. In the global statistics that were presented by Senator Sherry he seems to have forgotten the human element in which there are people working in vineyards and families supported by them. I base my remarks on the Crawford River winery, which is south of Hamilton in the south west of Victoria, run by the Thomson family. It is a typical small winery whose success is based on quality products and diversity from the big four wineries. The tax will particularly affect these types of wineries because of the price impact on their wines. Medium to high value wines can be expected to rise by $1 to $1.50 per bottle. This is laughed off by the government as not being a significant factor in the way consumers purchase wine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry laughed it off.

—Yes, Senator Sherry laughed it off. I can tell him that there is a point at which consumers will stop buying wine. It is most unfortunate for the smaller wineries if their share of the market is restricted because of this. However, since the sales tax was introduced in 1986, Crawford River has not increased its prices in an attempt to arrest the fall in consumption resulting from the tax. As Senator Spindler detailed, wine consumption fell from 21.5 litres per capita in 1985 to under 18 litres in 1990 and has only just recently picked up again to 18.5 litres. Another tax increase will postpone any non-tax price rises and further squeeze profit margins that have been shrinking from falling volumes.

PARA.TAB: Small wineries, such as Crawford River, account for over 700 of Australia's 760 vineyards and are important parts of rural and regional communities. With rural areas suffering under historically low commodity prices, wineries have provided strong community support. Farmers have been encouraged to diversify from sheep and cattle into wine.

Wine is a value added product and makes use of local goods and services in the production chain. Small boutique wineries attract large numbers of tourists to winemaking regions. There are four wineries in the area in which I live and they attract large numbers of tourists. Tourists while in an area will spend money on other local produce.

During a vintage Crawford River employs 20 to 30 pickers, the large majority of whom are female. Given that the nearest small town has a population of some 100 people, the impact of that income addition means increased economic security for a large number of families in that area. The Seppelt's winery at Drumborg, slightly further south, employs between 70 and 80 pickers and pruners during a vintage—and again the overwhelming majority are female. Other than seasonal work with vineyards, there is very little casual work available for rural women. This scenario is repeated again and again in the winegrowing areas of Victoria such as those that I have already detailed.

I would also like to point out that because smaller vineyards have restricted their investment in machinery and therefore employ large numbers of people, there is an even greater effect on employment in these areas. It is particularly important that they be allowed to continue those operations. Boutique wineries tend to be more labour intensive; the picking and pruning is done by hand rather than by machines. As a result, any fall in volumes from these types of vineyards will have a disproportionately high employment effect. I certainly join with my colleagues in emphasising the importance of this urgency motion and ask the Senate to adopt it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak as a West Australian from a winegrowing area too—not a major winegrowing area in the same way as South Australia is, although in 1991-92 we produced 9,673 tonnes of wine grapes. While it is only two per cent of total wine production, I think the quality of West Australian boutique wines in particular are attested to not only generally but also in this place. I can recommend the beautiful Cape Mentelle red in the Parliament House dining room as a good drop, but there are many other boutique wines in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am speaking as a red wine drinker and also a beer drinker. I speak as one who is proud of the wine industry not only in Western Australia but also Australia wide. I was in England recently and it was with immense pride that I saw so many Australian products on the shelves competing with the best that Italy and France can produce—and I think doing a lot better, certainly if the consumers are any judge.

I would be deeply concerned if I thought that any action of the government affected this important industry—I was going to say fledgling industry, but it is well past the fledgling stage. In this regard I am probably similar to a number of opposition senators and also Australian Democrat senators, but here I think the similarity ends. I also speak as a member of a government which has, I believe, over the past 10 years shown the courage to face tough decisions when those tough decisions are in the national interest. Those tough decisions are in the national interest now, and nowhere am I more happy to exercise this discipline than in relation to wine tax.

The position of the Liberals, indeed of the opposition generally, as I see a National Party member, Senator O'Chee sitting opposite—and he will notice that I am wearing my National Party jacket today—is understandable in the fact that it has now positioned itself as a result of this and other decisions of recent weeks as a permanent opposition. Opposition members are opposed to everything; they are no longer concerned about the economic consequences of what they do. They are prepared to be fiscal wreckers and spoilers, regardless of the national interest or of the economic consequences.

The position of the Democrats is a little more difficult to understand. They have set themselves up as the guardians of social justice whilst being economically responsible. I have been impressed with the way that Senator Kernot and the Democrats generally have managed to achieve the difficult balance that is often involved in the process of trying to balance economic ends with social justice ends.

TALK.START.PARA: —Social justice never registers with the coalition.

—That is right. But on the question of sales tax on wine, I would suggest that Senator Kernot and the Democrats generally—and I suspect under pressure from South Australian colleagues who have the numbers in their group—have thrown logic, social justice, economic good sense and the national interest over in favour of, I think, a cheap populism.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it does Senator Spindler any good to claim that the Democrats have been consistent in voting against progressive taxes of this sort since 1984. They have been consistent, yes—consistently wrong and consistently unjustified in the positions they have taken. `Monday Comment' by Ross Gittins in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald states:

By extending their objection to the Budget's indirect-tax rises to opposing the higher tax on wine, the Libs, Democrats and Greens have blown their cover. It's clear now that they're motivated by populism, not protecting the poor.

Tax increases of any sort are never popular. Politicians can always win themselves some cheap popularity by opposing them. On this occasion the opponents had a good argument: the Government's proposed increases in indirect tax were regressive. But that's not true of the wine tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Of all the budget measures, perhaps the most progressive is the wholesale sales tax on wine. Because it is a wholesale sales tax, the higher the product's price the higher the tax per unit of alcohol. There are big variations in wine prices. For example, let us take a four-litre cask of wine, which costs on average $7, and the same amount of Grange hermitage, about 5.3 750 ml bottles, which costs about $450. There is a big variation in prices according to the quality of the wine. A 31 per cent wholesale sales tax on the former, the four-litre cask of wine, will add 42c to the price. The 31 per cent wholesale sales tax on the latter, the same amount of Grange hermitage—5.3 bottles or, again, as close as you can get to four litres—would add about $27. The tax is clearly progressive, yet the Democrats are prepared to forego an extra $27 tax collected for that unit of alcohol at the top end of the market because of the 42c tax at the lower end of the market, which just does not make sense in terms of their social justice arguments.

PARA.TAB: To take the analysis further, the cheapest bottle of wine—at, say, $4—would increase in price by about 20c a bottle. A medium level wine—at, say, $15—would increase by roughly 78c a bottle. Each of these figures assumes that producers pass on all the increases. History has shown that in fact that is not what happens; only part of the increase is usually passed on and sometimes none of it is passed on, as in 1986.

Importantly, if we are talking about equity and progressivity, why should wine drinkers pay far less tax than beer or spirit drinkers? How is that fair by any standard? Because beer and spirits, unlike wine, are subject to wholesale sales tax and excise, they are taxed at a far higher rate than wine. Raising sales tax on wine from 20 per cent, which was the same level as soft drinks, to 31 per cent goes some way to closing this gap but only a small part of the way. Even with the increases in tax on wine, the wine industry enjoys a massive comparative advantage over both beer and spirits.

If these taxes are passed by the parliament—at present it is certainly looking as if they will not be passed by this chamber but they may be as members and senators become more economically responsible later in the game—the effective tax on alcoholic beverages, including excise, for the same quantity of alcohol would be 201 per cent for spirits, 80 per cent for beer and 31 per cent for wine. There is a big disparity still remaining regardless of the increase in the tax. So no argument against the tax has anything to do with progressivity, the application of social justice principles or any sense of fairness or equity. These arguments advocate taxing one group of drinkers more heavily than another based simply on their tastes and nothing more.

There is nothing new in the hysteria of the campaign surrounding this proposal. There is hysteria around any campaign where there is an opportunity to make changes. The only new element in this situation is the Senate and its numbers, the situation as I have said in which the opposition has positioned itself as a permanent opposition—spoiling, rejecting everything, not worrying about economic responsibility, not worrying about fairness, not worrying about social justice—and with the Democrats acting as opportunists determined to achieve some short-term popularity, regardless of the fairness of the proposals or the economic consequences.

No-one likes tax increases and any group facing such increases will fight them to try to retain their former, and in this case I would say privileged, position. So it is with the wine industry. But its arguments are flawed in a number of ways that have already been pointed out. I will just look at them, somewhat repetitiously, from a new angle. They are seen as flawed not only by the government but also by any sensible economic commentator—Ross Gittins is one that I have quoted but there are many others—and trenchantly, of course, by the brewing and distilling industries who have a vested interest as competitors.

They are not only annoyed at the unfairness of the tax disparity which applies between their drinks and those of the wine industry, but they are also, I think rightly—I say this despite the fact that I am proud of the wine industry—angry at the claims being made by winegrowers that theirs is the only industry that represents anything especially Australian or that it is the only industry that is especially important in terms of exports. That is utter nonsense. These other industries are equally important, particularly the brewing industry, which has had significant export successes. I say this even though, as I have said, I am a supporter of the wine industry and would not like to see it suffer in any way as a result of any action of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will be voting with us, then.

—I certainly will not be. The main thrust of the wine industry's argument is that the increased rate of tax will damage an increasingly successful export drive. This might make sense—it has already been dealt with very adequately by Senator Sherry—if the proposed tax applied to exports, but of course it does not.
—No-one here has suggested it does.
—The very urgency motion suggests it does.

—I agree with Senator Loosely; the very urgency motion suggests that it does. The industry suggests that it does and the opposition is just parroting the industry, so it seems that it is supporting its view. The industry argues that successful exports demand a substantial domestic market from which to spring. It needs as a springboard a big domestic market which is successful. I do not argue with that point either and it might make sense if it were not for the fact that the big four wine companies in Australia, despite the figures that we are given about the number of small winegrowers around the country, produce 80 per cent of the wine.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the wine industry today is not any longer a fledgling industry or a cottage industry. To the degree that it is, it is only at the margins. There might be lots of small wineries around but they are not the ones that are currently doing the exporting in the volumes that are going to be important. It might make sense if the wine producers were finding it difficult to attract investment but they are not, as Senator Sherry has already pointed out.

There should be, rightfully, concern at the estimated $1.2 billion that the industry needs in investment to meet its target of $1 billion worth of exports by the year 2000. But, again, as Senator Sherry has already pointed out, the BRL Hardy float, the South Australian Brewing Company wine division plans for the future and the floats in a number of smaller companies, all successful in recent months, attest to the fact that they are not having any trouble raising finance, and I predict that they will not in the future.

The industry is also aided by government initiatives: the reduction already announced in the corporate tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent; and the 10 per cent general investment allowance which is designed to address the run-down in agricultural equipment. Both of these commitments will assist the industry in a positive way. They show the government's support for industry policy, which Senator Spindler brought into question in his argument. So, again, the arguments about the impact on exports are nonsense.

Even the impact on the domestic industry is grossly exaggerated. Cask wine will be most affected—and that is agreed—since this is the most elastic end of the market. But even here, according to the Tasman Institute report—and the Tasman Institute is a very conservative institute—cask wine will face a decline in sales of only 3.8 per cent; bottled wine, on the other hand, is estimated to face a decline of only 1.3 per cent, which is less than the decline expected to be faced by spirits.

It also has to be said that previous increases in the tax on wine, both in 1984 and 1986, have not, despite what the opposition claims, had the disastrous effects predicted. There was a fall in consumption for a period, but that fall was paralleled by a fall in consumption in other alcoholic beverages; it was a fall due more to health choices than to price. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note that, of the original senators who took part in this debate last week, we have only Senator Sherry left—he must have done something wrong in caucus to have drawn the short straw. Even the generals have retired from this battle, the people who were in here trying to defend this measure last week, particularly Senator Evans and Senator McMullan. I do not see them in the chamber today taking part in this debate. They obviously have concluded, as Senator Beahan and Senator Sherry should have concluded, that one cannot really defend the indefensible.

PARA.TAB: This whole measure is indefensible mainly because, like many other measures that are in this budget, we did not hear very much about it in the last federal election. I was very involved in the last federal election, I can tell my fellow senators, and I cannot remember any proposal to increase tax on petrol; I cannot remember any proposal to put up the tax on cigarettes; and I cannot remember any proposal to put up the wholesale sales tax. I certainly cannot remember anything being done, or being suggested to be done, in a negative way in relation to long service leave.

I cannot remember anything about putting up the wool tax; I cannot remember anything about putting up the fringe benefits tax; and, as someone who comes from the Hunter, I certainly cannot remember any suggestion about putting up the wholesale sales tax on wine. If those opposite had suggested putting up the wholesale sales tax on wine, I assure them that their colleagues in the lower house, particularly Mr Fitzgibbon and Mr Horne, who come from or are associated with wine growing areas, would have had very different results in the election.

This government consistently told us lies before it got into government and the deception that it pulled on the Australian people comes about through all those measures that I have mentioned so far and, in particular, the measure that we are debating here tonight.

Last week Senator McMullan tried to cover all this up by saying that we did not know what we were talking about. He said that we were economic illiterates. Senator McMullan should come in here and explain to the Senate what is economically literate about a tax increase which cuts domestic wholesale sales from $1 billion to $900 million—that is a drop of $100 million—with a tax measure which will raise $79 million. They are great economics. Senator McMullan must have gone to the Alice in Wonderland school of economics to think that that is a great step forward for the industry.

What is economically literate about increasing a tax which cuts wine sales from 311 million litres to 279 million litres? That is a drop of 32 million litres. That is great for production and exports, but that is what this measure will do. What is economically literate about increasing a tax which cuts our export income by $126 million per annum and cuts the projected growth by the year 2000 from $1 billion in exports to $ 1/2 billion in exports? That will be great for the tax revenue base—it will not do much for production in this country and it certainly will not do much for employment in this country.

What is economically literate about a tax which cuts investment in new vineyards by $250 million? Senator West should be in the chamber because she comes from Orange. The next big wine growing area in New South Wales is going to be out near Orange. It is in the seat of Calare; Mr Simmons should be very worried about this. I do not see Senator West in here or crossing the floor wanting to defend a growth area in her electorate and, like the others, she has not come in to debate this matter at all. We ask: what is economically literate about a tax increase which cuts investment in inventories by $160 million and investment in winery plant and equipment by $335 million?

In the end, this shows how economically illiterate this government really is. It did not do its sums on this. It was admitted last week by the government that it had not run this measure through the Prismod model, which is supposed to model these various tax effects. In other words, the government just did not have a clue as to what it was doing.

The comment made last week by Treasurer Dawkins really demonstrates the prejudice this Labor government has against this industry. He said, `Well, we don't want to support the chardonnay set'. He obviously does not even know who consumes wine. The chardonnay set, as he calls them, makes up about three per cent of sales. The vast majority of sales is in cask and flagon wine sales to people who are buying wine at much cheaper prices, prices which are very competitive with those of beer and spirits—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not going to get tax cuts from this government.

—That is right. That is really the motivation behind this government's measures. The government, by taking these measures, I point out to honourable members of the Senate, is destroying an Australian industry. Let us get down to the nitty-gritty grassroots of where the destruction by this government is taking place. We only have to go 40 kilometres up the road from Canberra to find possibly the first person who could lose his business because of what this measure will do. As has been rightly pointed out by Senator Beahan, 80 per cent of exports in this industry are from big winemakers, but the industry is dominated by five big producers, and across the country there is a vast number of smaller wineries which will never become bigger wineries because of this government's measure and the way in which it has cut the ground from under this industry.

PARA.TAB: It reminds me a little of the Joan Kirner joke when she was running Victoria. The question was, `How do you get into a small business in Victoria?'. The answer was, `You start with a big one and wait'. That is the sort of thing that is happening with this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is happening in South Australia.

—As Senator Vanstone rightly points out, it is happening in South Australia. That is the reason why Premier Arnold in South Australia is so upset by this measure that he is spending $ 1/4 million on an economic study. Perhaps Senator Beahan and Senator Sherry should read that study—what a Labor premier has come up with—and what the effects are going to be.

PARA.TAB: I have mentioned our little winery out of Canberra at Murrumbateman: Helm's Wines. He is a small winemaker. Ninety per cent of sales come from big wineries but Helm's Wines is one of those smaller wineries which is having a very tough time of it. Exports are not available to these people because the return on the average sale overseas is only $3 a litre, and that is too low to cover their production costs. What the measures of those opposite will do is put those production costs up so that they will never get into the export market. We have the situation where smaller wineries have to give quite a lot of their wine away at shows and exhibitions—which they are taxed on and which reduces their profit even further. That sort of winery will go out of business under this government's measures.
So it has been rather amazing to hear the defence of this indefensible measure by those opposite. In question time on 30 August, Senator McMullan said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no evidence to sustain the view that the propensity to consume—
he uses that term to prove his economic literacy—
wine is so volatile that it will be affected. . .

Well, I think the points that I made earlier about the actual effect on this industry turn that into the lie that it is. It is not only little wineries outside the Canberra area that will be affected, but also small wineries across the Hunter and the Barossa, as well as wineries in other states. I have been absolutely amazed at how many wineries there are, for example, in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that some of the most trenchant criticism of this measure has come from the new member for McEwen. I will be quoting him a little later on. He has it right. He has seen the devastating effects that this will have on his industry. In my own area of the Hunter there is also a devastating effect. In the Hunter we have 11.5 per cent unemployment. One of the bright hopes of the area was the wine industry, including grape growing and winemaking. Hunter wines are some of the most famous in Australia.

As Mr Perry Gunner, Chief Executive of Orlando Wyndham, said, `This industry has been cut off at the knees'. Senator Sherry was trying to deny that last week when he told the story that $1 on a bottle of wine will not have very much effect at all. I told the story last week of Murray Robson, who has a winery in the Hunter. He told me that people who used to come through and buy a case at a time were now buying only half a case. If we multiply that sort of effect across the full range of sales, we can see it will have a devastating effect on those people.

Some of the comments that are probably the most biting in terms of showing that this Labor government really has it wrong have come from people on the government's own side. Mr Arnold, the Premier of South Australia, has urged the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to reverse his decision. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The results confirm our concerns that the Federal Government will not gain income from the move, rather it will cause serious disruption and downturn in an industry just beginning to make its impact on our export horizon.
The increased tax will severely undermine future investment decisions. We will not stand by and let this have a ruinous effect on our State.
As I have already indicated, I think the most telling comment came from Peter Cleeland, the new member for McEwen, when he said:
. . . the government should defer the wine tax rise to boost exports from the wine sector which had the potential to raise $1 billion in export earnings.
This potential can only be reached when the small vineyards are getting into the export market . . . a domestic market where they can produce enough cash flow to get into the export market.

Mr Cleeland rejects the Treasury argument that the sales tax increase will not harm wine exporters, describing it as `absolute nonsense'. I remind honourable senators on the other side that it is a member of their caucus who is saying this. I suppose he will not be popular for saying it, but it is good to see that he can get up and call a spade a spade. He said:
. . . it's about time we stopped listening to Treasury boffins. They've been wrong since 1983 and it's about time we told them so.

I would like to finish with the comments of Mr Ian Sutton, who really put the whole thing into perspective. He was talking about how successful the winemakers have been in getting into the export industry and how well they have been doing against overseas competitors. He said this about the government's measure:

With the stroke of a pen the Federal Government has effectively achieved what the French, the Germans and the Americans and others have been trying to do for years—erode our international competitiveness.
With friends like the federal ALP government, I do not think the wine industry needs any enemies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the proposition that is before the chamber. As I have been approached by honourable senators from both sides of the chamber to see whether we can conclude this debate prior to dinner, I will confine my speech to 10 minutes.

PARA.TAB: I think it is appropriate that today we should be debating the future of the wine industry, given that at a state reception for the President of Germany, Mr von Weizsacker, both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) referred to the strength of the Australian wine industry, to its capacity and its quality, and in particular took note of the enormous contribution made by the German Australian community to Australian winegrowing and winemaking. The president, in his remarks in response, took up those matters, making the point that he had sampled some Australian wine yesterday in the Barossa, South Australia. I will say a bit more about that later.

Like all the senators who have spoken in the debate this afternoon, I place on record the tremendous pride that I feel as an Australian that Australian wines are so well valued and well priced abroad. That is wine that comes not only from South Australia or Victoria—as perhaps might have been the case some time ago—but also from a number of vineyards right around the country, including Western Australia and Tasmania.

I am particularly proud of the wine industry that is located in my state of New South Wales, not only in the Hunter Valley and the Riverina, but also up on the mid-north coast. There are some very fine wineries, ranging from DeBortoli in the Riverina, which has won any number of outstanding prizes, to some of the great vineyards in the Hunter such as Cassegrain up on the mid-north coast. The New South Wales wine industry takes its place with the wine industry nationally.

The strength of the wine industry in Australia is, no doubt, to be found in its international perspective, in its outlook, and in its attitude. It is an industry based on excellence and on quality. It has definitely achieved a niche market in Europe, North America and, hopefully, increasingly Asia. In that respect I make a particular reference to the Japanese wine market.

I looked at the urgency motion—as drafted by Senator Vanstone and submitted to the chamber today—as I believe everyone should before they speak in a debate such as this. I make it a practice to try to analyse propositions that are before us. In respect of the urgency motion, the essential question to be asked is: does the motion advance the interests of the Australian wine industry one step? The answer to that has to be in the negative. But we can go beyond that. What actually would the urgency motion accomplish if carried? Does it have an impact upon policy? Does it have an objective that is either stated or implied from reading between the lines as to what the policy framework ought to be in respect of the Australian wine industry? Is there an alternative? Is there a suggestion that guarantees the Commonwealth revenue? Again, the answers to all these essential, fundamental questions have to be in the negative.

Is the proposition based on equity? Is there an equity consideration at heart? The answer to that is clearly no. Is there an efficiency concern? Again, the answer to that is clearly no. Does it give any indication whatsoever of an alternative coalition policy? Again, the answer to that must be no. Is it based on fact? Is it based on a reality in the Australian wine industry? Is it based on perceptions of realities—well, the answer to that might be in the affirmative—or is it based on what the opposition would like to believe is the reality?

Overwhelmingly the answers to those propositions, with the exception of the penultimate and ultimate questions, have to be in the negative. It is for that reason alone, in my view, that the Senate ought to say no to the proposition. It is not an urgency motion that ought to enjoy majority support. That is my view. I really believe that there ought be to some constructive element in a motion of this kind; there should be some purpose in the proposition.

Part of the duty of this chamber is to show a capacity to indicate a policy framework, to indicate policy goals, to indicate policy objectives. That is nowhere present in this urgency motion, as is the case time and time again with proposals that come before the chamber. Urgency motions give us an acute insight into opposition thinking, into what is in the collective mind of the coalition. As Mr Beazley said just the other day, the opposition in the Senate is bent upon cherry picking proposals that it likes and cherry picking proposals that it does not like—for endorsement or defeat. That is worthy of the United States Senate under Presidents Reagan and Bush. They cherry picked all the time. That is why the American budget was in the dire consequence it was in when Bill Clinton was elected. Cherry picking occurred in the Senate and in the House of Representatives in Washington.

Essentially, it is a negative approach to politics; it is a negative approach to legislation; and it is a negative approach to urgency motions. It lacks a purpose and it is defeatist in the sense that what the urgency motions say is that all change happens to be wrong, no matter what it seeks to do, no matter in what context it is operating, and no matter what the perspective of the government is. We have seen that for several weeks, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you are aware, as everyone on this side of the chamber is aware, and as the Democrats—Senator Kernot made this clear at question time—are aware. All we have seen from the opposition is delay, frustration and obstruction. Those opposite have become the guardians of gridlock in the Australian political system. That is how they are increasingly going to be seen by the Australian community. We have seen virtually no legislation being dealt with by the chamber. Senator Sherry might correct me, but I think we have spent less than 70 minutes in total, day after day, on legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—The opposition proposal is fatally flawed for those reasons. The guardians of gridlock become the defenders of delay, day in and day out.

PARA.TAB: Let us be candid about the approach that the coalition takes. It is saying that considerations of the Commonwealth revenue count for nothing, that budget strategy counts for nothing, that deficit reduction strategy over the ensuing four or five years counts for nothing. Day in and day out we have seen the impact of opposition thinking on the money markets. As the Prime Minister said yesterday, let us pin the villainy where it lies. It lies with Dr Hewson and the coalition. It is effective political vandalism.

The kind of political approach that we are seeing all too frequently from the coalition is ultimately devastating in terms of economic management, in terms of the approach that has been taken to the budget strategy, and in terms of the economic framework in which we operate. Continually we see simple acts of political bastardry. As I have said before, this chamber is now a mix of billiards and bastardry. We have loose balls ricocheting every time there is an intervention and we have deliberate malice from those opposite towards the government's program.

There is no doubt that the opposition's approach is flawed. The propositions before the country in terms of the government's legislative measures are simply based on equity. There is no doubt about that. Prior to 1984, there is no question that Australian wine drinkers enjoyed a privileged position. There is no question that the tax changes in 1984, in 1986 and, indeed, in 1993 still mean that, overwhelmingly, wine drinkers enjoy a privileged position. In seven years of Fraser government we saw no action based on equity in terms of the wine industry. The government's proposition is an equity proposition.

We have heard all these dire predictions of terrible consequences if the government's measure is embraced by the parliament. Look at the record. Exports of Australian wine between the years 1985-86 and 1992-93 grew from a mere $21 million—a base figure of only $21 million—to $289 million. That is an enormous increase and that is a matter of fact. The dire predictions of those opposite were made in 1984 and 1986. They simply did not materialise and they will not materialise.

I have no doubt that the $1 billion figure the industry has struck for itself in terms of exports by the turn of the century will be realised. This is an industry that markets itself on the basis of diversification, quality, sensible marketing strategies abroad, endeavour and innovation. There is no question about that. That has been the hallmark of the Australian wine industry. No doubt, we will see growth of similar dimensions in the years leading up to the turn of the century. As people have made clear earlier, the McKinsey report, the drop in the corporate tax rate, and a whole range of measures will assist the industry in its period of adjustment. The $1 billion is a reasonable figure that has been struck for export markets by the year 2,000 or so. I think it is achievable.

The opposition has no evident policy framework at all. Senator Tierney quoted Mr Cleeland. I respect Mr Cleeland for his views and, from time to time, he is absolutely right—we have to take issue with Treasury prognostications. I do not believe he is right on this occasion, but full marks to him for speaking up for what he sees as his constituency. In this respect though, I think he is wrong.

The government has been prepared to be fair and reasonable in dealings with the industry. In 1984 the wholesale sales tax rate was struck at 10 per cent; in 1986 it became 20 per cent. We are now seeing another increase that is based on equity, looking towards the whole range of beverages that are available to the Australian community. Despite the propaganda that has issued from some Liberal and National Party senators and some people in the other place, this tax does not apply to exports at all. The urgency motion is fatally flawed in terms of its logic. It has no impact whatsoever on exports of Australian wine.

The Australian wine industry flourished and grew, as I made clear earlier when reading the figures to the chamber, between 1985-86 and the current year. It continues to flourish and grow. We have seen evidence of investor confidence in the industry with the amalgamations that have been taking place and with the float of Hardys and the like. A number of small winemakers have also been successful in attracting investor confidence. The capital investment is there for the industry to grow. I believe the doomsayers will be proved wrong yet again. The urgency motion deserves to be defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I do not want to take up much time but, really, the arguments put by Senator Loosley display the baselessness of this government. The argument was put that members of my party are a bunch of vandals because they are choosing which budget bills they will and will not support. Senator Loosley conveniently overlooks the historical involvement of his party in the last years of the Fraser government and the attitude his party took at that time to budget bills. It is a case of saying one thing one day and another thing the next, whatever is most convenient, whatever gets it into power.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, Senator Loosley speaks on behalf of a government which went to the people opposing increases in consumption taxes. Once having gained power, it increased them. He speaks on behalf of a government which promised tax cuts and then delayed them. He speaks on behalf of a government that ran against any extra charges on students and then sought to impose them. He has failed to understand the argument which the opposition is running.

Our argument is simply this: an increased tax on wine will reduce domestic demand. It will increase industry costs because less wine will be produced at the same cost. It will reduce investment in the industry as wine production will be less attractive. The consequential effect of that will be the industry's incapacity to fund new plantings and winery upgrades, which it will need to do to meet its export drive. There will be a serious risk of quality degradation as people put in lesser quality grapes to try to cover the costs incurred domestically. Export prices will be put at risk because there will be a need to recoup the added costs the industry will experience as a consequence of both reduced demand and other increased sales taxes.

As I have pointed out, the export market we are in is a very fragile one. We cannot keep saying, `You are doing well. It will be all right; you can take on more costs'. Eventually that has an impact and the whole thing falls apart. That is something those opposite simply do not understand. It does not surprise me that this comes from a government that basically lied to people at the last election and, no doubt, will continue to do so.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY AFFAIRS—MANNER IN WHICH COMMONWEALTH PHARMACEUTICAL RESTRUCTURING MEASURES ARE BEING IMPLEMENTED IN THE ANNA BAY AREA OF NSW.
I note the above report by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

As you are aware amendments made to the National Health Act 1953 (the Act) in December 1990 established the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority (PRA) as a statutory body. These same amendments empowered the Minister to determine guidelines defining the criteria for decisions by the PRA. All decisions of the PRA are in the form of recommendations to the Secretary to the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services.

The Secretary, on receipt of a recommendation, then makes a decision under the provisions of the Act. In practice the Secretary has delegated the approval powers under section 90 the Act to officers of the Health Insurance Commission.

With respect to approval to supply pharmaceutical benefits under section 90 of the Act, the Secretary cannot make a decision without a recommendation of the PRA and can only agree to or reject a positive recommendation.
The Ministerial Guidelines relating to approvals in place at the time of the particular case in question where:

PARA.TAB: "3.For the purposes of paragraph 99K(l)(b) of the Act, the following are guidelines with which the Authority must comply in making a recommendation on the application by a pharmacist under section 90 of the Act:

(a)approval of a pharmacist shall not be recommended in respect of premises located within 5 kilometres by normal access routes from other premises in respect of which a pharmacist is already approved;

(b)approval of a pharmacist in respect of particular premises shall not be recommended unless the pharmacist demonstrates to the Authority that there is a definite unmet public need for that approval;

(c)approval of a pharmacist in respect of particular premises shall not be recommended . . . . . . if those premises are situated within 5 kilometres by normal access routes of other premises in respect of which there has been granted financial assistance under section 99ZC (amalgamation) or 99ZD (closure) of the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: While guidelines 3(a) and (c) are in this case not in question the original application and the subsequent application hinged on the demonstration of the "unmet public need" of the Anna Bay area.
What we have in this case is an applicant who was unsuccessful in 1991 and an applicant who successfully demonstrated the unmet public need of the area in 1993.
Clearly the unmet public needs of all areas without a pharmacy can fluctuate, especially for a growing area.
The question of unmet public need cannot be a purely objective judgement and the PRA collectively applies over 100 years of direct experience in community pharmacy to all applications.

It must be remembered that it is the task of the applicant to demonstrate the need to the PRA. Clearly there are very severe penalties under both the Crimes Act 1914 and the National Health Act 1953 for anyone proven to have supplied false or misleading information.

The Act provides for anyone aggrieved by a decision relating to him or her to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This is the appropriate channel of appeal and applicants are advised of their rights.

As the Senate Standing Committee in its report acknowledged, the first applicant did not exercise his prerogative to appeal to the AAT and is now aggrieved that someone else has been able to demonstrate that the area in question now has an unmet public need and has thus gained approval.
The Committee is assured that should either applicant seek relevant documents under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 every effort will be made to assist with request.
Yours sincerely
GRAHAM RICHARDSON
11 August 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for agreeing to deal with this motion formally and, I hope, to agreeing to the motion to refer this matter to a committee. Most senators will have received submissions from many constituents on the potentially horrendous effects of the proposed fringe benefits tax on business hotel accommodation and travel. The proposal to refer the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure will give the industry, unions and others directly affected by the proposal the opportunity of explaining in detail how the fringe benefits tax on business travel will mean a loss of jobs—some 10,000, or five per cent of the entire industry; the destruction of future employment prospects; and the stopping of investment—there is evidence of $29 million worth of capital investment projects disappearing already.

PARA.TAB: The fringe benefits tax will mean a regressive tax measure which will fall more heavily on smaller and less wealthy businesses; and it will mean an estimated 50 per cent reduction in the convention revenue—in the vicinity of $650 million—meaning exporting Australian business to Singapore, Bali and Hong Kong, further eroding the profitability of the industry. It will mean more regulation and, therefore, cost to business, estimated to mean by this measure alone an increase, for example, in Sydney of between 34 to 49 per cent in the cost of securing hotel accommodation and in country areas even more than that. Businesses are already burdened by the training guarantee levy, the superannuation guarantee level, payroll tax, workers compensation, sales tax and withholding tax, to name just a few.

Even the former ALP minister and tourism flunkey, John Brown, has recognised the real difficulties which will flow from the implementation of the tax and has suggested alternatives such as an increase in the departure tax. Interestingly, John Brown gave the real reason for this proposal when he said that it was `an antiquated philosophical dogma of the ALP, whereby Labor appears to have ceased its social maturation process and reverted to the worst aspect of envy and class warfare'.

By referring this matter to the committee, these issues can be argued, questioned and investigated and the committee will, no doubt, come to a conclusion which hopefully the government will implement. In a democracy it is essential that those whose investments are threatened, those whose jobs are threatened and those who understand the part that tourism and related accommodation and travel play in Australia's export earnings are given the opportunity of putting their case forward.

I congratulate the Australian Hotel Association and the various tourist organisations on the work they have done over the past few days to bring this matter sensibly to the attention of parliamentarians.

PARA.TAB: As a matter of principle, the government does not support the concept that the Senate should demand that a minister table documents which, by their very nature, are confidential. It was and is therefore confidential, as were and are the legislative drafting instructions in relation to the package.

At the time of the estimates hearing on 26 August, I was not aware that legislation would be required to impose the administration charge. Officers of the Australian Customs Service who were present at the hearing on 26 August failed to inform me of the fact that legislation was required. I explained that at the hearing only last Thursday.

I am able to provide the relevant documents for tabling. In doing so, I do not believe any of them—if the motion moved by Senator Ferguson had been carried—meet the description. The others are as follows: a briefing provided to me for the Senate estimates hearing of 26 August; a question time briefing provided to me on 30 August; and a copy of a minute of 19 August from the Australian Customs Service which details the status of budget related legislation.

My office never received one. I had not seen the minute until after the Senate estimates committee hearing of 26 August, and nor had my customs liaison officer who works in my office. I now table those documents. Again, I apologise to Senator Ferguson for not having made them available earlier.

As I said in the estimates committee last Thursday, I spoke to the customs officials, including the head of the department. As soon as I found out after the first hearing on 26 August that there were people present who knew, in general terms, about the need for legislation, I expressed my disappointment. I pointed out that it was unsatisfactory that none of them approached the table where I was sitting as we were having this discussion with Senator Ferguson. The head of the Customs Service accepts that it was an unsatisfactory performance.

I have also instructed the Comptroller-General of Customs to make sure that in future at estimates hearings it is not a matter of having the quantity of officers turning up to provide advice—20 or 30 officers—but of having the right officers. I discovered at the estimates hearing only last Thursday that Mr Stephen Holloway was not at the hearing on the first Thursday. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Firstly, I thank the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) for tabling those documents. Although I have not had time to read them, the commentary that was given with regard to those documents tends to raise more questions than it really answers.

PARA.TAB: This issue was first raised on Thursday, 26 August at the hearing of Senate Estimates Committee E with Department of Industry, Technology, and Regional Development representatives. I asked a series of questions under the inland revenue subprogram about the diesel fuel rebate scheme, because it was announced in the budget that an administration fee was to be charged.

This was to be a user pays scheme equal to one per cent of the total amount rebated to miners, farmers, hospitals, nursing homes and other off-road users of diesel fuel. Customs estimated that it would be rebating over $1 billion in 1993-94 and, therefore, this tax will raise about $10 million a year.

Prior to the hearing I sought advice about the difference between an administration fee to recover the actual administrative costs, and a tax which does not bear a direct relationship to the actual administration costs, either because the tax is more than the administration charge or because it is a percentage. My suspicion, based on information in the program performance statements, was that the so-called administration fee did not relate to the actual costs of administration and, therefore, was unconstitutional.

I asked questions in the estimates committee hearings on 26 August on this basis. Senator Schacht initially said that he did not know whether any legal advice had been sought on the issue and, if it had, it would not have been sought by the Australian Customs Service because its role was an administrative role. He said that any legal advice would have to be sought by cabinet as part of the budget process. The Hansard for the estimates committee hearing on 26 August states:

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as you know no legal advice has ever been sought?

The adoption of the policy of the rebate scheme and the issue of the rebate scheme itself is not an issue for Customs. We are just the administrating arm for whatever the policy side is. Customs is not the policy department in that respect.
