INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Schacht

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, but you are asking about legal advice. That would be a matter for policy in the context of the compilation of the budget. That is an area in which Customs would not normally, in my understanding, be involved. —`As I understand it.'

—I understand it myself. That is exactly what the minister said; it is in Hansard. I have to say that at the time I was very surprised about this, and still the minister seemed to be very uncertain about his information when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, it has been determined that it is not necessary for legislation to have an administrative fee . . .

The customs officials sat through Senator Schacht's initial comments about customs not being involved in providing legal services and did not seek to correct any of those statements. After the hour-long break, they sat through Senator Schacht's further comments about no legislation being necessary. Again, the customs officials did not seek to correct those statements. So I wondered if maybe there was a way to bring in this administration fee, which looked to me very much like a tax, without putting it into tax legislation. But what I could not accept is that no-one in the Australian Customs Service or Treasury had even considered the possibility that this might be a tax. I do not profess to be Perry Mason, but I have been on a farm long enough to know when I can smell a rat.

PARA.TAB: In question time on Tuesday, 31 August I asked Senator McMullan, who was representing the Treasurer, why the government was trying to disguise the tax as an administration fee and stating that legislation was not necessary; whether the government was intending to introduce legislation to implement the tax; and whether a draft bill was already in circulation. I was amazed when Senator McMullan said that he did not even have a brief on this matter. I wondered how a minister representing the Treasurer could not have a brief on an important issue like a new tax. After question time, Senator McMullan gave the following answer:

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to advise the Senate that it is a question that should have been directed to my colleague the minister responsible for customs because the matter is being dealt with within that portfolio, not within the Treasury. Nevertheless, I can advise Senator Ferguson that there is legislation currently being drafted by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel on instruction from the Australian Customs Service and the question should properly have been asked there.

PARA.TAB: There are two bills. One will be the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate Administration Charge) Bill 1993 and there will be the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate Administration Charge) Bill 1993. These administration charge bills respectively impose an administration charge—

SPEECH.PARA: still calling it an administration charge—

on a person in respect of the processing of an application for a rebate for excise duty or customs duty as the case may be . . . The bills are taxing bills. Two bills are being prepared because the diesel fuel rebate covers excise and customs duty, and having two bills avoids any chance of invalidity.
The minister continued later:
. . . that is the information that is available and it is a matter not being dealt within the department of Treasurer nor any area which I represent, but I am happy to provide information to him.

Senator McMullan's answer raises two very interesting points. Firstly, someone must have been burning the midnight oil in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, because less than five days before, Senator Schacht had said that he did not believe legislation was necessary, yet during question time Senator McMullan was able to provide the Senate with very detailed information about this new tax.

PARA.TAB: There would not be one bill, as I thought, but two. Not only that, but also two bills were being prepared `because the diesel fuel rebate covers excise and customs duties, and having two bills avoids any chance of invalidly'. Obviously someone had put a lot of thought into it. I would have thought that it would have taken a lot longer than the intervening Friday, Saturday, Sunday or Monday to come up with that sort of detail. When I had taken note of the answer, Senator Schacht said:

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ferguson raised the issue, quite rightly, that one does not need legislation if it is an administrative fee, but the administration fee cannot exceed the cost of administration. I also conceded that if there were any doubt, there would have to be legislation. There is now to be legislation.

—Whether there is doubt or not, as a result of the discussion on Thursday night—

SPEECH.PARA: this is the Thursday night of estimates—
my view was that there ought to be legislation.

It appeared to me that Senator Schacht was saying that it had not occurred to anyone in the Australian Customs Service, Treasury, the Treasurer's office or anywhere else, prior to Thursday, 26 August, that taxing legislation would be necessary but Senator Schacht, realising that I had raised some valid concerns, had now decided that legislation would be necessary.

PARA.TAB: At best, I was concerned that public servants and ministerial staff, who are supposed to be far more expert than I am in this area, had completely overlooked the fact that legislation might be needed. At worst, I was concerned that the government was trying to put through what could well be a tax as an administration fee. Whatever the situation, I just could not believe that the government had only considered introducing legislation for this tax after I raised it in estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said.
—It is.
—I explained today—
—Senator Schacht did today.
—And at the estimates committee last Thursday that the legislation was part of the budget process.

—If Senator Schacht will bear with me I will show how I can connect these various things. PARA.TAB: Following question time on Tuesday, 31 August I gave my notice of motion, which I tried to move as a formal motion today, asking that information and several documents be laid on the table of the Senate including any legal advice provided to the relevant minister or departmental officials; any copies of memos or briefing notes supplied to the Minister for Science, Small Business and Customs either before or after the hearing of Senate estimates in relation to this matter; and advice as to the date on which the decision was taken to implement this administrative fee in tax legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is proposed to re-open the hearing on Program 9.3 to facilitate further discussion on the diesel fuel rebate levy.

SPEECH.PARA: The department received details of the proposed admin fee from Treasury some days before the date of budget. That is right. Drafting instructions were actually sent on the 17th, which was the day of budget.

PARA.TAB: Not only that, we were told at that meeting that there were customs officials present on 26 August who knew about this draft legislation and who did not speak up. The parliamentary secretary, Senator Schacht, made several comments about this. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There were officers here who generally may have known, but they did not inform me . . .
Another quote:
A lot of people generally knew this was around . . .
And:

I was not informed during the hearing while you were asking those questions. I have made it clear to the department that I should have been informed that legislation was being prepared. And so, on behalf of myself and the Customs Service, I apologise for that.
Senator Schacht even said:

PARA.TAB: I am not sure that we have got to the bottom of all this yet. I believe there are still several questions that remain unanswered. Fifthly, why did Senator Schacht not formally advise the secretary of Senate Estimates Committee E, either on Friday 27 August or on any other date between then and Thursday, 2 September, that misleading information had been provided to the committee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)that there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before 5.00 p.m. on 7 September 1993, by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), a statement of the results and outcomes of the running of the Treasury model, Prismod, for the following items:

TAB.TAB: (i)the distributional effects on households of the 1993-94 Budget measures, both as before the changes announced by the Government and after those changes were announced, as at 1 July 1994, 1 July 1995, 1 July 1996 and 1 July 1997 compared with before the Budget (incorporating relevant bracket creep for those years and using leaded petrol consumption based on current patterns), and

(ii)the impact of the Budget measures, both as before the changes announced by the Government and after those changes were announced, for all industries covered by the model as at 1 July 1994, 1 July 1995, 1 July 1996 and 1 July 1997 compared with before the Budget and, in particular, the detailed impact on the wine industry; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)that the statement include details of all relevant assumptions (behavioural and others) upon which the results and outcomes of the application of the model were predicated, to assist Senators in their consideration of the Budget bills.

The budget that was brought down on 17 August and the subsequent amendments announced by the government—some of which I think are going through the House of Representatives tonight—will have an enormous impact on many individuals, families and industries, not just this year but in the medium term right through to 1996-97. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has released a partial modelling of the impact of the budget which almost miraculously reveals that almost everyone is better off with virtually no detriments. But that analysis is incomplete and it is also deliberately constructed so as to put the best possible light on the budget measures.

PARA.TAB: The way that works is that the distributional analysis that has been given takes into account 1993-94, which is the only year in the four-year period in which there are tax cuts. The benefit of those tax cuts erode throughout the four-year period that the government is really concerned about. The government says that its real bottom line priority is the budget outcome in 1996-97, not the outcome in the intervening years. Yet all its modelling is on the first of those four years, not the last.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made claims, as has the Treasurer, based on this modelling to argue that the budget is neither regressive nor unfair, or leaves middle or lower income households worse off. Without the information that I am seeking on behalf of the Senate in my motion, senators will be unable to form an opinion as to whether the budget is all the things that the government says that it is. In particular, is it regressive? Does it have a harmful impact on certain households or industries?

The information that I am seeking is obtainable. Eighteen months or more ago, at the end of 1991 or early 1992, this modelling and the information that derived from the modelling were extensively used by the Treasurer and Prime Minister in their attack on the coalition's then Fightback proposals. Indeed, the Treasurer at that time put out a statement in March 1992, at which time papers were tabled by him relating to the analysis that the Treasury had done on the coalition's Fightback measures, which said, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: Analysis conducted in Treasury using the new PRISMOD model—
for the uninitiated, which includes most of us, Prismod is short for `price revenue incidence simulation model'—
shows that the Opposition's claims—
in terms of the distributional impact of the Fightback proposals—
are incorrect.

He went on to show the results of the modelling that the Treasury then did, which included the indirect tax changes that the coalition was proposing, the effects of bracket creep, a hypothetical roads charging proposal that had earlier been examined by both the coalition and the government, and illustrative households specific price effects of the health proposals that were contained in Fightback. So that was all available as a result of the modelling of Prismod back in 1991-92. The ability of the model to do the same is obviously still there. Just last week, on 31 August, the Treasury released a fairly detailed statement headed `Distributional analysis of budget measures'. The first line of the press release said:
In the Budget Press Conference of 17th August—
that is, budget day—
I indicated that I would be releasing a distributional analysis of the Government's proposals in the weeks ahead—this Press Release contains the results of that analysis.
He went on in fairly considerable detail about all of that. He also said in that press statement:
The results from the distributional analysis of the Budget measures (including, where possible, the modifications announced last night)—
that was the budget mark 2, I think—
conducted by Treasury using the Price, Revenue and Incidence Model, PRISMOD, model are attached. Additional material will be released in due course.

He also said that it had been possible to model many of the revenue measures in the work that he then presented. So the government has already released some of the distributional analysis. But it is incomplete because it deals only with a one-year effect, in essence, which takes into account the full effects of the personal income tax cuts in year 1 but which does not take any account of the erosion effect of those tax cuts over the period beyond the first year. We had quite a lengthy debate in Senate Estimates Committee D about this matter last week. I will not go into all the details of that other than to say that on page D154 of the Hansard for estimates D for 1 September there was an exchange between myself and Mr O' Brien, an assistant secretary of the tax policy division of the Treasury, which went as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prismod includes, does it not, outputs for industries?

PARA.TAB: Mr O' Brien—Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Therefore, I assume that it could show the impact on different industries of particular policy measures?

PARA.TAB: Mr O' Brien—Yes, it has been used that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you done, in relation to the budget, an impact analysis on the wine industry of the 55 per cent increase in the sales tax on wine?

SPEECH.PARA: Then Senator McMullan intervened and stopped the debate going much further on that. But it is quite clear from that exchange, plus many of the exchanges in estimates hearings last week, that the information that is being sought by the coalition in the notice of motion on behalf of the Senate tonight is certainly available. All we are asking for is the same analysis that has been done on previous occasions. It is a very important point. The Senate has an obligation to the people of Australia to scrutinise the government's legislative program, including, in particular, its budget proposals.

PARA.TAB: If we are going to be able to uphold our requirement of holding the government to account to the people of Australia, then the full information has to be available in terms of the basis of some of these very important budget decisions that have been made. Indeed, the Senate would be failing in its responsibilities if it were to allow a government—any government—to legislate such a major program as its budget without disclosing the fundamental basis upon which it is built or the likely impact that it will have on those affected.

The Senate is very soon to refer the government's revenue bills to Senate committees for detailed examination. That examination and proper due process will be very sorely deficient without the information being sought in this motion. Therefore, those are the reasons in essence why on behalf of the coalition I have moved this motion. I hope it will have the support of the Senate because, without it, we will not be able to do our job properly in terms of the thorough and proper examination of all the impacts of this very important budget on all Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in the previous discussion concerning the procedural arrangements for dealing with this matter, the government will be opposing this motion strenuously because the Senate is seeking here not the presentation of some documents in the interests of open government which are being in some way hidden; we are seeking here documents that do not exist, documents for which there is no reasonable justification for them being created and which would be of limited, if any, value if produced for reasons which I will go into in a moment.

PARA.TAB: In the interests of brevity—and I appreciate that Senator Short was relatively brief in his remarks, and I will be the same—I would refer senators or anybody else who was interested in the detail of this to the lengthy discussion that took place at the Senate estimates committee hearing in which the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Evans, sought to point out to Senator Short the reasons why the documents which he is seeking to have manufactured would not be of value or useful.

If we come to the conclusion that without these documents it is not possible for the Senate properly to discharge its obligations, we have to conclude that the Senate has never done its job properly because we have had more documentation of this sort about this budget than about any budget ever before. Such documents have never been presented before and there has never been more information provided about a budget than has been provided about this one. I make it very clear that the government will not be acceding to this request.

Mr Evans sought to explain patiently and carefully to the Senate via the estimates committee that Prismod is a static model; it is inherent in the nature of such models that that is necessarily so. It is one of the reasons why I do not have a great deal of faith in the use of these models as tools. I have grave doubts about the extent to which people place reliance on them. It is the sort of illusory comfort and the appearance of certainty that some bottom line number out of a computer can produce when, if we are honest with ourselves, we know that there are significant inadequacies in trying to reduce the complexities of a society and an economy to a computer model that will just produce some reliable outcome.

Prismod does not take account of any impact on the dynamics of the economy of the measures that are being assessed, including behavioural change assessments, and all changes are assumed to impact as if they occurred overnight. That is a very brief description—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you say that about Fightback?

—We did—exactly that. My distinct recollection—I do not want to mislead the Senate—was that is what we did say. It is a while since I bothered to look at that document. It has not been relevant for a few months, so I have not spent much time looking at it. I think that is right. It was certainly the impression Mr Evans gave me, listening to what he said at the estimates. But I would not want to bet my life savings on it because I am relying on my memory of it. The model has not changed; its capacity has not changed.

PARA.TAB: The question of bracket creep is irrelevant in this sort of analysis for the reasons which Mr Evans outlined. I was saying, before Senator Tambling interrupted me with his interjection, that I am being very brief in describing what I see as the shortcomings of any documentation that might be produced in response to this request in the hope that people who are interested in participating have seen or read the record of the discussion at much greater length which took place on this matter so that I do not take up the Senate's time reiterating that which has already been done.

My distinct understanding, advice and recollection of Mr Evans's comments to the estimates committee are that the nature of the material fed into Prismod does not make industry specific analysis meaningful. It may even be right to say that it cannot do industry specific analyses. I understood Senator Short to be saying something opposite in reference to something an officer said before the estimates committee. He was reading from the transcript. It is not the context in which I remember those statements being said. As I am going from memory, there may be more to it. Certainly it is not very meaningful; it is arguable.

My advice is that Prismod, because it is based on household expenditure data—that is what is fed in—is not capable of doing industry specific analysis. So part (a)(ii), on my advice, just cannot usefully be done. Part (a)(i) cannot usefully be done and, as Mr Evans pointed out, the request about bracket creep is not relevant for that sort of analysis.

Part (b) of the resolution does not stand by itself. If part (a)(i) and (ii) are not carried, part (b) does not make any sense and no-one would pretend that it did. But, in any event, to the extent that there is a request independently to provide information about the assumptions underlying any analysis by Prismod, they were outlined in the Treasurer's press release of 31 August. The analysis requested by Senator Short is, in large part, not consistent with the capabilities of Prismod.

It is getting absurd when the Senate has a long debate about not seeking the provision of documents that have been created but the creation of some dubious and in some instances, I am advised, impossible econometric modelling in the hope that it will provide some illusion of certainty such that it might be able to better discharge the obligation that the Senate has been discharging for 92 years without any such pretence.

I do not wish to take the time of the Senate by reiterating more than the brief outline of why this is an absurd proposition. Modelling is inherently limited in its usefulness, but to seek to get it to do functions of which it is not capable is an absurd proposition. Prismod is, by its nature, a static model; it takes snapshots at a particular point. One can take a series of snapshots, but as one gets further and further away I think the usefulness of the snapshots gets less and less and the dynamic processes by which one got from A to B are not capable of being measured by Prismod. One may wind up at point B rather than point A but one has no way of working out how one got there by virtue of Prismod. It has no capacity to provide that sort of information. As I said, Prismod is household expenditure based. As I understand it, it cannot do industry specific analyses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasury said it did.

—That was not my advice before and nor is it now. I heard the quotes Senator Short gave and I note that he was not listening earlier, but I do acknowledge that he made that point. It was not my understanding of the context in which those comments were made, but Senator Short was quoting and I am not going to challenge that here tonight because I do not have that evidence in front of me. I thought Mr Evans said the opposite. It is certainly not my advice now and it is not my understanding of what one would expect to get from an econometric model of household expenditure data, which is what we are talking about here.

PARA.TAB: Prismod ignores a large range of outlay measures which benefit lower income recipients in the economy, but they are not capable of being modelled because they cannot effectively be allocated by household or by household type. So even if one could do all these things—

TALK.START.PARA: —So how did you do it for Fightback?

—With all the qualifications that we said about this and about what those opposite proposed, there were a large number of the opposition's most inequitable proposals in Fightback which were not assessed because they were not capable of being distributed by household type. In fact, Fightback was much more inequitable than Prismod showed and we made that clear in the analyses. I did not ask Senator Short to raise that. If he wishes to raise Fightback again, I am very happy to discuss it with him any time anywhere in Australia.
—Your own paper said that you did take those things into account.

—Go back and read it. It is six months since I saw it because it has not been relevant for quite a long time. When I last saw it we were saying that some of the opposition's most horrendous proposals could not be assessed because they could not be modelled by household type. Some of them could and they were taken into account. Some of our outlay proposals can be assessed and they are taken into account in this proposal, but not all.

PARA.TAB: Prismod also ignores possible dynamic factors which would make a series of static snapshots of the type proposed here irrelevant. I do not think a proposal such as this does the Senate any good in its seeking to have, if it is seeking to have, public assessment of its reputation enhanced when it seeks documents which either cannot be provided or, by any sensible assessment of their usefulness, should not be provided. Not only do we oppose the motion but I think there is no prospect that the government will accede to the request in the resolution should it be carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this motion, but not for the reasons which I think the coalition hopes. We think that if we are to have further revelation of the capacity of computer models, it will accentuate the inadequacy of these models and demonstrate the grave problems to be faced by anybody relying too greatly upon what the models purport to reveal.

PARA.TAB: It is apparent to us—I think it should be apparent to anybody with any commonsense or any knowledge at all about computers—that, by definition, a computer model will only deliver what the programmer wants it to deliver because that is why it was programmed. Whoever programmed Prismod has designed it to do a certain job.

The Democrats will not oppose what Senator Short is proposing here as we believe that it will demonstrate the limits of this computer model and perhaps add a little more to this debate than just one side of politics claiming that its computer model is better than the other. The more we add to that, the greater potential for understanding there is of the limitations of these things which are supposed to deliver some credibility to a philosophical stance which has been taken for political reasons.

So often, so much of what is budgetary hyperbole is in fact based not on accuracy or a knowledge or a capacity to predict the future, but rather on the political philosophy which is seeking to be justified by some degree of credibility which attaches from using the word `computer' often enough for people to say, `Well, if the computer says it is so, it must be so'. We hope that by revealing the inadequacies of Prismod that thesis will be tested sorely. In fact, Senator McMullan has assisted us greatly with that tonight by sharing with us his grave concerns and his lack of faith in a computer's bottom line, suggesting to us that which we have feared for some time—that there is an over-reliance on the computer's credibility.

There is a new group of young Australians—I suspect that the average age of this group is actually getting younger by the month—who are computer literate enough to understand their limitations and also understand that the games you can play with computers are just that—games—and that they bear very little relationship to reality. Computer modelling programs which purport to model the whole of civilisation are being sold in retail stores throughout our cities at this very moment. In fact, there is one called `Civilisation'. It is a computer modelling toy and the various assumptions which have been made in that particular game are readily accepted as assumptions by people from eight years old to 80 years old—anybody with the commonsense to realise that it is just a game and that there is no credibility attached to the assumptions made.

There are many others. There is even a computer simulation game, `Castles', based on the concept that we are living in medieval times. The assumptions upon which that is based are that one is a ruler and that one distributes one's wealth and makes the sorts of decisions that medieval rulers were supposed to make. If one gets all of those cliches right, fits the model and understands the assumptions, then one becomes a more successful ruler. I know eight-year-olds who are capable of understanding that the assumptions there are not connected with reality. I know of eight-year-olds who are able to deal with the assumptions upon which the computer game `Simearth' is based. That game simulates the entire earth and asks you to rule it based on assumptions.

This business of looking at different computer models and suggesting that they bear some relationship to reality is something that even eight-year-olds are able to cope with. To trot computer models into this place and seek to grasp at some sort of credibility which is attached to the fact that they are generated by a computer is quite childish. I hope that by seeing more of the inadequacies of these computer programs and these computer simulations we may be able to raise the level of computer literacy in this place to such an extent that we no longer attach this mysterious credibility to something which is given a bottom line by a computer.

I am glad to hear that Senator McMullan has little faith in a computer's ability to attach credibility. I am glad to hear that the government understands that Prismod, by its very nature, is a static model and cannot be used to deliver a prediction of the future, but I am disappointed at the level of credibility that is attached to any of the information that is delivered by these programs. To cower behind the defensive line of `our computer model says' really does not deliver credibility to the person conducting the argument. The Democrats will be supporting this motion for those reasons.

I was fascinated to watch the discussion which was held between Senator Short and the Treasury officials during Estimates Committee D. I watched as Senator Short asked whether the computer model could provide information for things it had not been designed to provide. I was not convinced. I was more interested in the perambulatory manner in which the answers were delivered to his questions. I thought much more succinct answers could have been given to many of the questions and I thought the answers were, to a large extent, evasive and not helpful.

If any other justification is necessary for supporting this motion, it is perhaps the suggestion that the Senate requires full information, whatever it is and whatever its level of credibility. Perhaps it is that more information is supposed to be better than inadequate information. I do not believe that this will deliver adequate information, but it is in the hope that there will be increased literacy in terms of what is capable of being delivered by computers that we support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to point out that, at Senate Estimates Committee D on 1 September, I raised the question of whether Prismod would be able to give a realistic assessment of how the budget measures would impact on rural Australia and particularly on Tasmania. I was particularly interested in how the increase in fuel excise on marine fuels would impact on my state of Tasmania. I am sure that was a matter of interest for all honourable senators from my state and probably from other states as well.
—You got your answer.
—Yes, I did get my answer and the answer was that Prismod was not able to provide an accurate assessment of the effect of that fuel excise.
—Did you really expect that it could?

—To be quite frank, I did not know, but I am trying to get a handle on how that is going to affect my state. If people are saying that Prismod shows that the overall effect of the budget is going to be not disadvantageous to people in general and it is unable to show how it is going to affect people specifically my state, then obviously more questions need to be asked and more information needs to be made available. To the extent that Senator Short's motion might elicit that information, I will support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take more than a few minutes of the Senate's time. Senator McMullan has said that we all know why this motion is being moved. We on this side are not quite sure why the government is seeking to break a long time convention—almost—in this place that the parliament does not sit when the allotted time for party meetings occurs each Tuesday morning. With respect, I thought Senator McMullan's colleague, when he became a little excited earlier today, was somewhat misleading when he suggested that these meetings, in effect, are not part of the legislative process and that, therefore, senators should not be paid except for the time that they are in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: In fact, as the government knows, the meetings of caucus and of our party room are essential in order that the legislative program proceed in an orderly and sensible way. Caucus has to be convinced by its ministers to support the government's legislative program and we have the opportunity in opposition to debate and reach a position on the government bills in our party meeting. For as long as I can remember, those meetings have been held on Tuesday morning in this place and, as I said, a parliament never sat when the meetings were being held because that would simply fail to recognise the importance of those meetings as part of the total procedure.

What the government is asking us to do tomorrow morning is abandon that long held practice in order that the Senate might sit for a few more hours. I am not opposed to that. In fact, I think the Senate should have sat for many more hours this year. The Senate would have almost sat for a record few days this year. It has been somewhat embarrassing to senators, certainly on this side of the chamber, how few days the government has required this place to sit during the course of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't deal with legislation even when we do sit.

—Rubbish. The Senate could be sitting a sensible time rather than simply a few weeks. How many weeks has the Senate sat this year—and we are now in September—six weeks? I know we had the election, but then the government came back for only a very short time. The Senate should sit longer hours—more sitting days than it has at the moment—but that is not a reason to break this convention.

PARA.TAB: In fact, I am somewhat bemused as to why the Senate is only sitting two days this week. I understand the IPU is meeting in this building next week, but why is the parliament not sitting on Wednesday and Thursday of this week? It may well be that there are preparatory meetings of the IPU which are going to occupy certain committee rooms around this place later in the week. But this is the largest parliamentary building in the world; there must be room for the IPU to take a few committee rooms whilst the parliament continues.

There is no reason that I understand why this parliament cannot be sitting on Wednesday and Thursday of this week. If it were sitting on Wednesday and Thursday of this week, there is no reason why the convention that we do not sit during party meetings should be broken by the government. That is the concern we have. That is why we say to Senator McMullan: why cannot the government get its sitting days in order and organise a program that can deal with its legislation, and we will sit that program and the job will be done, as I have said, in an orderly and sensible way.

The only other point I want to make, because there are some around here who have decided it is opportunistic to win a few cheap points on the state of the legislative program—I will not repeat the things I said earlier this day about what has happened over the last few weeks—is to remind the Senate that the estimates committee process was in place for all of last week. As a matter of interest, one of the estimates committees, I have just remembered, is sitting on Wednesday this week, all day. So, in actual fact, this parliament apparently, through a committee, will meet on Wednesday of this week. If that is the case, why cannot the chamber sit on Wednesday of this week? The government runs the program and we sit the hours the government requires; that is really basically how it works.

Not only have all the estimates committees been meeting for many hours, which is the most time consuming part of the appropriations process—which Senator McMullan failed to mention earlier when he was arguing that so little legislative work had been done—but also so many of the bills which ultimately have to be debated are currently before the legislative and general purpose committees, which is also part of the legislative process.

Just in case the government has not caught up with what has been happening in relation to its program, I remind those opposite that the following bills are all currently before committees: Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill, the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill, the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Consequential Amendments Bill, the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill, the Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill and the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill.

In fact, we have even been referring issues to legislative and general purposes committees relating to bills before the bills get here in order that those bills might ultimately be dealt with more expeditiously than otherwise. One wonders what more can be reasonably done to facilitate a government that simply cannot get its program in order and, therefore, has to break the conventions of this place in order to require it to sit while party meetings take place.

We understand why Prime Minister Keating wants a shortened caucus meeting or no caucus meeting tomorrow; we have read it all in the papers in the last week. But we should be able to conduct our processes in the normal way, the way that has been respected by governments in the past. No case has been made out by the government why that tradition should be broken in this instance.

Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Senator Panizza:
That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report on or before the last day of sitting in March 1994:

PROCTEXT.PARA: The operations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS) and any other body, company or corporation which receives funding from ATSIC, with particular regard to:

PARA.TAB: (a)the accountability of ATSIC, ALS and ATSIC-funded bodies and individuals for the way in which they receive, spend and publicly account for taxpayers' money with particular reference to project grant money;

(b)whether there is an effective working relationship between the Department of Social Security and ATSIC and endeavour to identify the factors which have made some community development and employment projects (CDEP) successful whilst others have failed and the reasons for this;

(c)whether it is appropriate for ATSIC to continue funding all of its current programs, with particular reference to the CDEP, or whether greater levels of accountability could be obtained if responsibility for that program were transferred to the Department of Social Security;

(d)whether there are sufficient guidelines, controls, checks and acquittal procedures applied to ATSIC, ALS and other ATSIC-funded bodies to ensure that taxpayers' funds are fairly and properly applied for the purposes intended under the ATSIC Act, especially concerning the levels of spending approval authority and effective use of capital item expenditure;

(e)whether there are sufficient guidelines and procedures in place to control satisfactorily the expenditure of taxpayers' funds on travel and accommodation by ATSIC commissioners, councillors and staff, and by members or employees of any ATSIC-funded body; and

(f)whether ATSIC should continue to hold discretionary power to disregard non-compliance with conditions applying to grant money which it has distributed, or whether the ATSIC Act should be amended to require the refund of such money where grant conditions are not met.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion, which is an initiative of Senator Panizza, is very important. I remind the Senate that it deals very specifically with issues arising from the operations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the government's funding programs in that very important and finance-consuming area of government administration.

PARA.TAB: I also remind the Senate that this is the International Year of the Indigenous People. The government continually has a number of very important initiatives and considerations before the parliament in connection with the programs associated with Aboriginal reconciliation. There are a lot of program expenditure priorities currently before the Senate and the estimates committees.

The Mabo issue of native title for Aboriginal people is taxing and concerning many people. Social justice is a matter that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has very properly raised. He has said that as part of the package of legislation that will be associated with Mabo there will be a second phase and a second packet of social justice priorities to be presented to this parliament early next year.

So in addressing this motion, which seeks to refer a number of very important issues and considerations to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry, we should be asking a number of important questions. What are Aboriginal people saying? What are Aboriginal people criticising with regard to government and the community? What are Aboriginal people requesting?

I share the concerns expressed by Senator Panizza. Many Aboriginal people are asking for a proper accountability and a proper consideration. What should be our response? Certainly, our response on behalf of that Aboriginal constituency in Australia ought to be to use the process that is available and hold a Senate inquiry. This inquiry is timely and it certainly is appropriate.

The various tenets of the motion that has been put forward by Senator Panizza could very easily be summarised under a number of headings. The first one is accountability. The second is the effective working relationships between various government departments, agencies and programs, including whether those program delivery services are actually being appropriately delivered by each department or agency, and whether programs should be transferred to other agencies or departments.

Senator Panizza also referred to the very important issues that arise from capital expenditure in the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. This certainly needs addressing. Then, of course, there are the more routine and administrative issues that arise from the procedures, funding, travel and accommodation for Aboriginal representatives themselves in Australia, particularly those on ATSIC. Finally, the motion deals with the very important issue of noncompliance with conditions for which very generous and very appropriate grants have been made for Aboriginal people.

Firstly, I will deal with accountability. It is obvious, upon consideration of the operations up until now of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, that there does need to be a further examination of the whole area of accountability. The Senate estimates committee reports to this parliament have made that very clear. Senator Panizza and I have both taken a very close interest in a number of the issues that have been pursued by Senate estimates committees. We are well aware that the office of evaluation and audit, inside ATSIC itself, has raised many of these issues.

On behalf of Senator Panizza, at the preliminary discussions the other evening concerning ATSIC I asked questions with regard to the activities of the fraud control area inside ATSIC. The officers placed on the record a number of very concerning issues that are being pursued internally within ATSIC at this time. There are, of course, additional inquiries such as those being conducted at the moment by the Australian National Audit Office into the Aboriginal benefits trust account and the land council operations in the Northern Territory, with which I am familiar.

Senator Panizza also raised the very important issue of the effective working relationships between departments and agencies. This parliament has become aware that there are a number of conflicts in these areas. The achievements and targets that the government has very properly set for each of those programs need to be very carefully monitored, checked and balanced. In particular, we need to look at the outcomes of the Aboriginal deaths in custody recommendations, to which the government responded with very specific budget requirements in the previous financial year and in the current financial year. Major areas of expenditure flow through to the areas that are addressed in this motion for inquiry.

Capital expenditure is now very timely in Aboriginal communities because of the issues that will arise under the proposed legislation for Aboriginal native title. Capital expenditure goes hand in hand with any provisions anywhere for land and land administration. There is a need to check and look at pastoral properties and estates and the expenditure that has taken place in a cooperative way between the federal government, its ATSIC agency, and the West Australian government, particularly the former Labor administration. I know that Senator Panizza will have a particular interest in Western Australia in this respect.

I am aware that listed on the current Notice Paper is legislation which is designed to review the administrative mechanisms of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. This important legislation addresses a number of very important areas of review, many of which pick up recommendations made in the previous parliament by the then shadow minister, Dr Michael Wooldridge. Many of those recommendations have now been picked up by the government and appear in the legislation that is currently before this parliament.

An inquiry into finance and public administration of the sort that has been proposed by Senator Panizza will complement the debate that will take place on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation. Consideration will be able to be given to the important area of administrative changes and mechanisms that the government is now proposing in this whole area.

The final point in this motion refers to whether or not there is adequate compliance in the area of grants to Aboriginal organisations. This is most important. Very good and proper grants are made to Aboriginal organisations throughout Australia. However, projects often fail because there is no follow-up; no recurrent expenditure is built in. For example, a youth centre in a community in the Northern Territory was built with a very generous grant. There was no follow-on finance in the following financial years either for programs or for repairs and maintenance. The entire project failed because of that.

In addressing this motion, I draw attention to the fact that in all areas we must apply consistent Public Service standards to the major statutory authorities such as ATSIC. Anything that government or the parliament legislates for in the area of Aboriginal affairs today ought to very clearly focus on improved employment for Aboriginal people, particularly in their participation in the private sector rather than their dependency on government.

Five hundred participants at a conference in Alice Springs this very week will be actively looking at the business interests and commercial opportunities available to Aboriginal organisations and Aborigines throughout Australia. I will be attending that conference this coming Wednesday. I know that the Special Minister of State, Mr Walker, will be there. It is an important conference. We need to ensure that the focus comes back very clearly to the priority of employment for Aboriginal people in self-sufficient small businesses and for private sector employment rather than a continual dependence on welfare agencies and government.

The other area that needs to be very specifically addressed is the effectiveness of the health and education programs. It is Aboriginal people themselves who are demanding these reviews. In this Senate I certainly hope that the Australian Democrats and the Independents will take a very keen interest in this particular committee reference. We have a responsibility to the Aboriginal constituency of Australia to ensure that this type of timely and appropriate review is established.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, ENVIRONMENT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The schedule, page 4, lines 6 and 7, proposed paragraph 8(2)(b) of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, omit the proposed paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(b)such other number of members as is provided for by an enactment, following a referendum to enable the electors of the Territory to choose the number of members to be provided for in that enactment.".

SPEECH.PARA: 2.The schedule, page 4, after proposed subsection 8(2) of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, add the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "(3)A referendum referred to in subsection (2) shall be held in accordance with Part 4 of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988, the provisions of which shall apply, so far as they are capable of application with appropriate changes, as if:

TAB.TAB: (a)references in that Part to alternative voting systems and options were references to two or more alternative numbers of members of the Assembly; and

(b)references to the Minister, the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Leader of the Australian Democrats in the Parliament were references to the members of the Assembly for the time being holding those positions.".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments were not foreshadowed in my speech at the second reading stage. The effect of these amendments would be to address the amendment by the government which seeks to confer on the ACT legislature the capacity to determine the number of representatives in that legislature. The amendments which are proposed by the Democrats would consider that number of representatives in the legislature in terms of a referendum to be conducted in the ACT, by the ACT and responded to by the ACT electors.

PARA.TAB: It is the belief of the Democrats that that is a much more appropriate way of addressing the problem than the manner proposed by Senator Ian Macdonald's amendment which seeks to retain that authority within this federal parliament. We believe the ACT electors appreciate the capacity to have within the territory a government which is not overshadowed by big brother here, but rather a government which determines its own future. However, there are some concerns about allowing the executive government unfettered opportunity to determine the number of representatives. With all that in mind, the Democrats propose that such a decision be made by the electors of the ACT in full through a referendum. It is for those reasons that we propose these amendments. I think that explains the amendments sufficiently.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been better if the amendments had been moved separately. So far I have not had an explanation of amendment No. 2.

—Amendment No. 2 makes sense of No. 1 because it describes how it will happen. The essential effect is to replace that part of the government's amendment which proposes to grant to the ACT government the capacity to determine its numbers. Having omitted that paragraph, amendment No. 2 describes how that will be done. I do not think any further explanation is warranted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes both of the Democrats' amendments which have just been circulated. In our legislation we are giving the power to the territory assembly. If it chooses to hold a referendum to increase or decrease the size of its House of Assembly that is its business. I am not quite sure of the mechanical section in amendment No. 2. I ask Senator Bell: who decides the question for the referendum? Say there were a proposal to increase it by two, or to decrease it by two, or put it up by six; who decides that issue to go to the referendum? Is that the House of Assembly itself? If it is, why not leave it with the power to have a referendum outright?

—The question is whether it is only the legislature of the ACT which has that capacity and also whether the determination of the question is left to the assembly. The answer is no. By requiring, as in this amendment, that a referendum be the mechanism by which the numbers are changed, the sovereignty remains with the electors rather than with the legislature. The need for that was demonstrated in the recent move—which the Democrats supported from the very beginning—to determine the electoral system for the territory. It was our constant position.

PARA.TAB: In the face of vehement opposition from this government and, at various times, from various parts of the legislature of the ACT, we held out for a referendum. We were justified and vindicated in that position not only by the decision to hold a referendum in the ACT but also by the very result of that referendum, which supported our original position. It is consistent with that position that we hereby propose a referendum to determine this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since being appointed shadow minister, these are the first dealings I have had with the Australian Democrats, and I find the experience rather amazing. I was not aware that the matter was being called on—that is not the fault of the Australian Democrats—and I came in here and found these, I suppose, not so terribly detailed amendments for me to look at for the first time, as I am catching my breath. When I proposed my amendments, I telephoned Senator Bell and told him what they were about. He indicated that he would support them. When I got here I found these amendments and I do not even know what they are about. I am opposing them simply to give myself a little time to try to work out what they are all about. I was going to say that I do not even have a copy of the Australian Capital Territory's Electoral Act to see where the amendments fit in, but I see that my staff did diligently put a copy in the file, so at least I have it, but I have never opened it prior to this time.

PARA.TAB: Whether the second amendment proposed by Senator Bell is in order is something I simply cannot say because I cannot read that quickly, particularly while I am speaking. In some way I have to delay the procedures sufficiently just to let me check that that part is appropriate. It is not that we are about to embark upon some amendments which do not mean anything or which are in the wrong act or which are inappropriate. It is certainly something that I, on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, want to look at more closely than I have so far.

The thrust of what Senator Bell is proposing is similar to the thrust of the amendment I foreshadowed and will be moving. That simply is that the Liberal and National parties do not think that the current ACT assembly should be left in a position where it can determine what the numbers of the assembly will be. It was for that reason that I foreshadowed—and will move—the amendment that the determination of how many members there should be in the ACT assembly is one which, as at present, remains with this parliament. If there is to be any difference in the number of members—that is, 17 members—of the ACT Legislative Assembly, the ACT government would have to convince the government, convince the lower house of this parliament and convince this chamber that there was a need to alter that from the current number of 17 to some other number. I indicated in my speech on the second reading debate that if a good case was made to this parliament and, certainly, to the Liberal and National parties for amending that number of 17, we would not object, we would be objective about it and we would consider the matter on its merits and so determine it, but we did not think that the ACT assembly should have that power.

Senator Bell, through his amendment, wants the same result. He does not want the ACT parliament to be left with that power and obviously has the same concerns that we do—at this stage of the maturity of the ACT government. So Senator Bell and the Australian Democrats also have that problem. Their solution to it is different from the one that I have proposed. As I understand it, their solution is that the number shall be 17 or such other number of members as is provided by an enactment following a referendum, which will enable the electors of the territory to choose the number of members to be provided for in that enactment.

All along the line I suspect that it shows a belief that someone else should determine it. It then becomes a question of whether it should remain as is—that this parliament and this chamber should have the final say on who does it—or whether there should be a referendum of the people of the ACT.

Having clarified that in my own mind as I talk—Senator Bell indicates to me that I have at last got it right—I will say that we oppose the Democrats' amendment and will seek support for our foreshadowed amendment.

I do believe that the cost of having a referendum simply to determine this matter would probably outweigh the democratic ideal of having it done. I have not had a chance to consider that cost or what other problems there might be with it. But, on the spur of the moment, suffice it for me to say that leaving things the way they are at the current time is the safest way to go.

If Senator Bell were, in the fullness of time, to propose that we might take other action and were to consider the ramifications of it, perhaps that is something we could look at some future time. At this time we would oppose the Democrats' amendment. I will be moving my own amendment, which leaves things as they are, so that this chamber and this parliament, for the time being, maintain control over the number of members in the ACT assembly.

I am a fraction concerned that if we vote down Senator Bell's amendment—which the government has indicated it will do—he will abide by his original undertaking to support our amendment. It is important that the ACT assembly, just for the moment, not be given that power.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long is a moment?

—Until an appropriate time or, as I said in my speech in the second reading debate, until further amendments foreshadowed by the minister in his second reading speech following a review. The wording was that more—

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht says that the government will abolish the ACT assembly. I note that interjection. It will make interesting reading in the Canberra press tomorrow that the government wants to abolish the ACT assembly.
—I did not say that I wanted to abolish it. I said I wanted to find out what the review was about.
—I suppose I should respond to that interjection so that Senator Schacht is on the record as correcting what seemed to me to be what he was proposing.

PARA.TAB: In his second reading speech, the minister said that possibly more important changes were being examined and would be included in a separate bill at a later date. That bill will obviously come back to this chamber later, with possibly more important changes. If Senator Bell is able to talk to us at greater length about the reasons behind his proposal when the bill comes through, we might be able to have a look at it then. For the moment my attitude and the attitude of the Liberal and National parties is that we will oppose the Democrat amendment but proceed with the amendment that I will move at the appropriate time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of brief remarks about both amendments. We have now had two general elections for the ACT assembly. During that period there have been two different governments in power in various combinations in the ACT assembly. Whatever the views of the national parliament are about the governmental structure of the ACT, it is now well accepted that self-government is here to stay, although there was considerable controversy some five or six years ago when it was first proposed.

PARA.TAB: We all know that in the first election some very odd people got elected on the basis of `No self-government for the ACT' and then in the period afterwards joined coalition governments to become part of the government of the ACT. I believe that one of the most breathtaking moves one can make is to oppose self-government, get elected on that basis and then join the government whose establishment one has opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might have been part of the plan.

—It might have been part of the plan. We recognise that some of those people who were elected at the first election were, to say the least, a little bizarre in their political philosophy. But following the second election most of them have now gone. There is a stable government in the ACT, though it is a minority government. The government believes it would be very odd to say that the ACT assembly should not have the powers that are possessed by every other federal and state government and the other territory government of Australia—that is, the Northern Territory government. I refer to the absolute power of those governments to decide their own numbers.

PARA.TAB: Since the Northern Territory got self-government in the mid-1970s it has increased the size of the Northern Territory assembly. That has had more to do with trying to preserve some seats. But it is one vote one value by and large in the Northern Territory and the size of that parliament has been increased. The average enrolment in the Northern Territory is still only about 2,500 to 3,000 electors per member of parliament per constituency. Members of parliament who represent such small numbers get paid full parliamentary salaries for a full-time job.

In the ACT, the 17 members represent individually a much larger proportion per elected member than is the case in the Northern Territory assembly. Therefore, it is very odd to say to the ACT government representatives, `After two elections and having established self-government, we still cannot trust you to make a decision about the members of parliament that you wish to have'.

It is quite clear to the government that these amendments—that foreshadowed by Senator Ian Macdonald and those moved by Senator Bell—deal more with the constituencies of their own political parties in the ACT than about any power that could go to the dominating political force in the ACT, which is the Australian Labor Party. So I do not think either Senator Bell or Senator Ian Macdonald have put forward their views based on totally altruistic reasons. They are more to do with the internal machinations and politics of the parties they represent in the ACT assembly.

Therefore, the government will oppose these amendments. We think it is unreasonable to put something on the ACT that is put on no other parliament in Australia, including the Northern Territory assembly, which represents a lot fewer people, because of its smaller population, than does the ACT assembly. Therefore, we believe that the amendments are unreasonable and will oppose them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to Senator Schacht. There is in every other parliament a system of checks and balances which can—
—Not in the Northern Territory.

—Well, there is an administrator and a series of checks and balances. It is appropriate that there should continue to be a check and balance in relation to a matter that goes to the fundamental point of the ACT parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is not the assembly as such that we have a concern about, it is this government. As Senator Schacht quite rightly points out, it is a Labor government—and when can we ever trust a Labor government with either money or the constitution? Some of its factional mates in the ACT assembly are not doing terribly well at the moment. There seems to be a continuing bloodbath in the ACT assembly—it is called Blue Hills on ABC radio—and it seems that there are a lot of people without jobs who probably want jobs. It would be so easy for the government to increase the number to many more than 17—

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not have a majority in the assembly.

—It has the support of a couple of so-called independents. They are a bit like the Australian Democrats—they are on their own until the crunch comes and then they crawl over onto the left of the government. I think that is the situation in the ACT assembly as well. There are a couple of independents who are more left wing than even the left-wing faction of the Labor Party. We are concerned that they might manipulate the situation to suit their own factional purposes.Going the other way, they might decide to reduce the number by skilful calculation to ensure that no other political party could ever hope to achieve a majority in the ACT assembly. It is not an issue that we raised.
—You are talking more about Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland than the ACT.

—Senator Schacht does not have to talk to me about Bjelke-Petersen because I lived through that. Honourable senators do not often find me defending a lot of the things that happened then. But whatever happened in Queensland decades ago has no relevance or significance to my speech.

PARA.TAB: I know about the sort of Tammany Hall tactics that the Labor Party has indulged in all of its life. Senator Schacht knows that better than I. Senator Schacht and Senator McMullan are the secretary type people that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) talked about so disparagingly. They know what that is all about; they know those things.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are the true believers.
—I did not think the Prime Minister was talking about true believers when he spoke about former party secretaries; I thought he had other things in mind.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is concerned that the ACT assembly might do what Labor parties everywhere do: fiddle the books and fiddle the rules to make the numbers such that no other party could ever have a say in the parliament. My understanding of the electoral system is that that could very well happen. I am very concerned about that.

I am rather nonplussed by the fact that the Democrats, while seen to be sharing that view, are prepared, as I understand from Senator Bell, to roll over again and go along with the government on this proposal if its amendments do not get up. I am finding it a little difficult to work out from Senator Bell just what the situation is. I really do not know whether he is just—to use a colloquialism—pulling my leg or whether he really means what he says. Every time I ask him he bursts into laughter and I am not quite sure what he is referring to.

So that I can fully understand the matter, I ask Senator Bell, as the mover of the amendments, whether he would explain to me just what a referendum would mean. As I indicated before, I have not yet had the opportunity of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just vote against it.

—No. I have not had the opportunity of looking at part 4 of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 to which he refers. If Senator Bell is serious about moving these amendments, I would like him to convince me by taking me through the part entitled `Referendum to Choose Electoral System' and indicating to me how the provisions of his amendments would apply to that. I will also get him to indicate to me whether there is a cost factor involved in doing those sorts of things. We might then be able to consider that proposal rationally. I want him to indicate whether there is anything else in part 4 of the electoral act which we possibly should look at in considering his proposal.

PARA.TAB: When I say that I am going to vote against the Democrats' amendments and propose my own, I suppose that with some decent debate and decent arguments Senator Bell could convince me differently. When I inquired of Senator Bell why this amendment was not brought to our attention, he said, `We've only just drafted it'. I asked when that was and he said that that was at 9 o'clock this morning. That was 13 hours ago. I have been around the parliament all day. I would have thought that just a fraction of courtesy might have been appropriate. We could have had a look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not debating manners here.

—We might be debating that for the next half an hour. I do not know when we are proposing to adjourn tonight. It is a rather novel proposal by the Democrats to have a referendum of the ACT electors. It is something that I suppose, given a fraction more time to consider and consult with the people of ACT, I may agree to. We are a party that does listen to what the people say. The Labor Party by contrast, as shown in the budget, has no worry whatsoever—
—You have done nothing else for 3 1/2 years but abuse the Democrats.

—With such rowdy interjections, I can barely hear myself think. The Labor Party is not interested in consulting with the people who are affected by its legislation. We have only to look at the budget. It apparently did not even consult with the ACTU.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. This is a committee stage on a specific bill. It has nothing to do with the federal budget. Can we just get on with the committee stage?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—I think we do have a problem with relevancy. I ask the honourable senator to be relevant to the bill before the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asking the mover of the amendments to tell me more about the proposal in his amendments regarding the Australian Capital Territory.
—Sit down so that he can answer your question.

—I want to make sure that he is absolutely clear as to the question I am asking him, because I have had a rather unique experience with Senator Bell. Those opposite laugh because they have all been through this before; they obviously know how to treat the Democrats and what they say one day. My colleagues used to tell me about that.

PARA.TAB: We are very interested in these amendments. I want to find out just what its ramifications are. I would like to consult with the people of the ACT. As the shadow minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we going to taxi around to several big hamburger joints tonight to find out?
—There are representative people from the ACT available. I could ring Ms Follett and see what she thinks of the idea. Has Senator Schacht spoken to her since he became aware of the amendments?
—She supports this bill.
—Does Senator Schacht know what she thinks about the amendment?
—If she supports the bill, I presume—
—I would like Senator Schacht to check with Ms Follett. Maybe we should check with the Independents.

—I did not quite hear Senator McMullan's interjection, but there are other people and groups in the ACT assembly who might want to be consulted. Perhaps the Trades and Labour Council in the ACT assembly might—
—Why are you trying to filibuster?
—If perchance we did not finish with this by the time we got back to it tomorrow, perhaps I could have a talk with Senator Bell or ring Ms Follett to see what she thought about it.
—The first bit of legislation we get and you talk it out.
—We can very easily deal with the matter now. All I need is an undertaking from the government that it will support the amendment that I am going to move and we can get it over and done with.
—Yours is wrong in principle.

—It is not wrong in principle. The Democrats indicated to me that they thought the principle was correct. They also indicated that they were going to support this proposal. Apparently, they had some meetings and, a mere 13 hours ago, decided to change their mind, but they did not bother to tell me about it. Without the benefit of some private explanation from Senator Bell, I am now inviting him to explain to me just what this will mean—how it will work in practice, what the cost might be, what representations he has taken on the issue and what sort of consultation there has been—so that I can consider these matters. I invite Senator Bell to assist me.

—In explaining this amendment to try to relieve Senator Ian Macdonald of some of his confusion, I thought I was fairly specific in describing the consistency of this proposal and the position we held, for example, on the issue of the electoral system to be adopted by the ACT. The Australian Democrats argued long and consistently that a referendum was the appropriate mechanism for determining the electoral system, and we argued that in the face of consistent opposition from those who wish to impose upon the ACT what we thought was an inappropriate electoral system. Consistent with that approach, we have proposed this opportunity for the ACT electors. After consultation with those electors—I am not suggesting for one moment that I have consulted with all the electors of the ACT—we had sufficient responses to guide us to the view that it would be an acceptable, consistent proposition to have the issue determined by referendum.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ian Macdonald asked specifically whether there was any indication of the sorts of costs that would be involved in that. Our earlier proposition for a referendum on the electoral system was dismissed by a number of opponents on the basis that it would cost in the order of $1 million to deliver the decision making capacity to the electors. Senator Ian Macdonald, because of his intense interest in the ACT, may remember my direct question in this chamber some years ago about the cost of such a matter. I do not know whether that was before Senator McMullan developed his interest in the ACT. I was able to participate in that debate about that particular election and illustrate that such a referendum, even if held independently of any other election, would not produce a cost of anything like $1 million. As a matter of fact, it would have been closer to an amount less than $200,000.

Regardless of the eventual cost, the order of the cost is something which raises the question: what is the price of democracy? In this instance, I would suggest that such a question would usually be coincidental with a general election within the ACT and the cost at that time would be incidental to the conduct of the major general election. This is consistent, of course, with the Democrats' support for the concept of citizens' initiated referenda. Although it is not necessarily the exact mechanism, the idea of regularly consulting electors with various questions at times of general elections is a concept which has been supported, especially in local government throughout Australia, and is gaining increasing acceptance.

What I am proposing here is but a shadow of that. When this question was raised by Senator Ian Macdonald, I said that the Democrats would be entertained by the question, and the amendment that I propose here is the result of our consideration. I really think Senator Ian Macdonald has illustrated for future reference the fine art of filibustering. He asked a question which had been answered in the first two minutes of my explanation of these amendments. He asked that question not only several times, but also in several different ways. If I need an illustration of filibustering when I am speaking to school groups, I shall use this example that Senator Ian Macdonald has so aptly provided tonight.
